LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Republic of the Philippines 
 
The proposal comprises (i) a program cluster for three loans under the 
Development Policy Support Program (DPSP) covering reforms in fiscal 
policy,  governance  in  public  financial  management,  the  investment 
climate, and social inclusion; and (ii) a proposed loan of $250,000,000 
for subprogram 1 of the cluster.  
 
Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Law, economic management and public policy 
Subsector: Economic management 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, governance, private sector 
development 
Subthemes: Promoting macroeconomic stability, public governance, 
private sector development 
 
Category C       

 
The  core  objective  of  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Philippines 
Development Plan (MTPDP) is high and sustainable economic growth, 
with job creation and poverty reduction. Poverty rates have declined in 
the  Philippines  in  the  past  two  decades,  but  the  absolute  number  of 
poor people has increased to over 26 million. The second quarter 2005 
Social  Weather  Survey  reported  that  as  many  as  57%  of  household 
heads perceived their households to be poor. The critical fiscal situation 
that  emerged  in  2002  has  compressed  public  investment  and  funding 
for the social sectors, which in turn has been a drag on achieving higher 
economic  growth  and  has  hurt  the  poor.  These  problems  have  been 
compounded  by  poor  governance  in  public  expenditure  management, 
corruption in procurement, and a weak investment climate.  

Reforms supporting fiscal consolidation, strengthening governance and 
reducing  corruption  in  key  government  agencies,  and  improving  the 
investment  climate  and  infrastructure  are  crucially  important  to  putting 
economic  growth  on  a  more  sustainable  path,  re-directing  spending 
toward the social sectors, and contributing to poverty reduction. These 
measures are taking place in the context of the government’s adoption 
of  a  Medium  Term  Expenditure  Framework  (MTEF)  which  explicitly 
links  the  overarching  objective  of  poverty  reduction  to  fiscal  discipline, 
strategic  prioritization  in  the  allocation  of  resources,  and  effective 
implementation of budgeted programs and projects.    
 
The Government has implemented a series of measures to address the 
fiscal  imbalance,  resulting  in  a  swift  and  impressive  turnaround  in  the 
fiscal  situation  and  improved  macroeconomic  stability  in  2006.  The 
DPSP  cluster  supports  the  Government’s  efforts  to  improve  the  fiscal 
situation  and  to  broaden  the  reform  program  in  four  target  areas:  
fiscal  consolidation,  macroeconomic  stability,  and

ii 
 

 

creditworthiness; (ii) deepening reforms in public financial management 
and  anti-corruption;  (iii)  investment  climate  and  infrastructure,  and  (iv) 
protecting  the  social  sectors.    The  reform  program  was  prepared  by  a 
joint team of representatives of the Government of the Philippines, the 
Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. 
 
The  DPSP  will  support  the  Government’s  efforts  to  (i)  achieve  and 
sustain  higher  economic  growth  and 
reduce  poverty  and 
unemployment.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  DPSP  cluster  will 
undertake strategic reforms to: 
 
(i) 

restore fiscal sustainability, maintain macroeconomic stability, and 
improve  creditworthiness  by  enhancing  the  quality  of  fiscal 
management  through  raising  tax  revenues,  strengthening  tax 
administration,  reducing  inefficient  spending,  and  strengthening 
the debt management strategy; 

(ii) 

(ii)  enhance  governance  in  public  expenditure  management  and 
support  the  Government’s  measures  to  reduce  corruption  in  the 
revenue-collecting  agencies  of  the  Bureau  of  Internal  Revenue 
(BIR) and Bureau of Customs (BOC);  
improve the investment climate by clarifying and strengthening the 
legal and regulatory framework for investments and infrastructure; 
and  

(iii) 

(iv)  protect the social sectors by improving the access to and quality of 

social services, and enhancing poverty monitoring and targeting. 

 
A  loan  of  $250,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  will  be 
provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending  facility  for  subprogram  1  of  the  Development  Policy  Support 
Program. The loan will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 
3  years,  an  interest  rate  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  and such  other  terms  and  conditions set 
forth in the draft Program Loan Agreement.1 
 
The  program  cluster  period  will  be  from  November  2004  to  December 
2009, with a single tranche loan of $250 million to be disbursed under 
subprogram  1  when  the  Government  has  met  the  conditions  for 
effectiveness.  Subprogram  2  will  be  submitted  for  Board consideration 
approximately  12  months  after  the  effectiveness  of  subprogram  1, 
subject  to  the  Government’s  readiness  to  continue  with  its  reform 
agenda.  Subprogram  3  will  be  submitted  for  Board  consideration 
approximately  12  months  after  the  effectiveness  of  subprogram  2, 
subject  to  the  Government’s  readiness  to  continue  with  its  reform 
agenda.

funds 
generated  by  the  loan  proceeds  to  meet  program  expenditures  and 
associated costs of reform and to help maintain current levels of social 
expenditure.

The  Department  of  Budget  and  Management  (DBM)  will  be  the 
Implementing  Agency  responsible  for  implementing  the  Program,  and 
shall  be  supported  by  the  relevant  line  agencies  of  the  Borrower, 
including  the  Office  of  the  Ombudsman  (OMB),  Department  of  Public 
Works  and  Highways 
(DOH), 
Department of Education (DepED), and Department of Agriculture (DA). 
A  DPSP  coordinating  committee  (the  Committee)  chaired  by  the 
Undersecretary  of  DOF  and  comprising  officials  from  DOF,  DBM,  and 
the  National  Economic  and  Development  Authority  (NEDA)  will  be 
responsible  for  coordinating  the  implementation  and  the  sustaining  of 
the DPSP actions with the Borrower’s DBM and relevant line agencies 
of  the  Borrower  involved  in  supporting  the  Program.  The  Committee 
shall  meet  quarterly 
the 
implementation  of  the  Program,  and  provide  guidance  and direction  to 
the Executing Agency and DBM.   
 
The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The loan proceeds 
will  be  disbursed  to  the  Borrower  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans. 
 
The  DPSP  will  provide  significant  benefits  and  will  have  a  positive 
impact on the poor.  
 
(i)   Progress  in  fiscal  consolidation  will  help  to  restore  confidence  in 
the economy; promote macroeconomic stability; and foster broad-
based  economic  growth,  job  creation,  and  poverty  reduction. 
These  are  the  cornerstones  of  the  Government’s  MTPDP  and 
PDF. 

(ii)   The  increase  in  tax  revenues  will  enable  more  spending  on  the 
social  sectors  and  this  will  have  a  direct  positive  impact  on  the 
poor. 

(iii)   The  reforms  will  improve  governance  in  public  expenditure 
management,  including  the  implementation  of  the  medium-term 
expenditure  framework  and  procurement  reforms.  Anticorruption 
initiatives will reduce wasteful spending and allow the Government 
to re-orient expenditure to the social sectors. 

(iv)   Transaction costs for business will be lower because of reductions 
in  red  tape,  the  elimination  of  all  export  fees  and  charges,  and 
other investment reforms. The better investment climate will open 
economic opportunities, increase investment and productivity, and 
lead to economic growth, higher incomes, and more jobs. 
Improvements  to  the  infrastructure  will  increase  the  long-term 
growth potential, create jobs, and raise incomes. 

(v)

Risks and 
Assumptions 

 

The  Program  is  firmly  embedded  in  the  MTPDP,  the  Philippines 
Development  Forum  (PDF),  and  ongoing  fiscal  consolidation.  The 
assumptions underlying the Program include the following.   
 
(i)  Macroeconomic and political stability will continue. 
(ii)  The  economy  will  be  able  to  withstand  external  or  domestic 

shocks. 

(iii)  The  Government  will  stay  on  course  with  key  policy  reform 

measures, and will liaise effectively with Congress.  

 
However, there are risks to the Program.  
 
(i)  Political  instability  could  affect  the  pace  of  reform  and  the 
performance of the economy. However, although the considerable 
political  disturbances  during  2005  had  an  impact  on  spreads  on 
international bonds, domestically the reforms moved ahead, albeit 
with a delay.  

(ii)  The  elections  for  Congress  in  2007  will  not  affect  policy  actions 
under  subprogram  1  as  all  the  policy  measures  had  been 
completed  by  mid-October  2006  before  Board  consideration  in 
early 2007. The elections may delay legislative reforms and slow 
the  reform  momentum  in  2007  if  there  are  personnel  changes  at 
the  senior  level  in  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies. 
However,  many  of  the  triggers  for  the  subprogram  2  involve 
implementing  legislative  reforms  in  2006  or  executive  orders  and 
thus the risk to the overall reform agenda is relatively low.  

(iii)  The  external  environment  may  deteriorate  if  persistently  high  oil 
prices  result  in  a  slowdown  in  world  economic  growth  and  trade, 
and create unfavorable conditions in world financial markets. This 
would translate into slower growth in the Philippines and increase 
fiscal stress. However, to a certain extent this may be mitigated by 
the  Government’s  policy  reform  package,  which  includes  tax 
reforms  and  a  reduction  in  wasteful  public  spending  through 
rationalization. 

(iv)  The Government may lack the commitment to implement reforms 
and 
there  may  be  weak  coordination  among  government 
agencies.  However,  the  Government  appears  strongly  committed 
to  the  DPSP  reform  program,  which  is  embedded  in  the  MTPDP 
and the PDF.  The Government has taken a clear policy stance on 
the  need  for  rapid  policy  adjustment  on  the  domestic  front 
following the fiscal and macroeconomic instability of 2002–2004. 
implement  reforms  may  be 
to 
constrained  by  lack  of  resources  and  other  emerging  priorities 
during  elections  in  2007.  However,  many  donors  are  also 
supporting the reforms through technical assistance.  

(v)  The  capacity  of  agencies 

(vi)  There  will  be  resistance  to  the  reforms  from  vested  interests. 
Institutionalizing  governance  reforms  in  BIR,  BOC,  and  selected 
line ministries is likely to be a long drawn-out process. There have 
been  disappointing  outcomes  in  recent  high-profile  corruption 
cases. However, several factors will mitigate these risks. First, the 
DPSP  strategic  approach  is  to  focus  efforts  on  supporting 

  

v 

in  BIR  and  BOC,  and  (b) 

Government’s  initiatives  (a)  to  improve  integrity  in  revenue 
collection 
to  strengthen  public 
expenditure  management  in  four  key  national  agencies  with 
significant  procurement  budgets  (DPWH,  DepEd,  DOH,  DA). 
Second,  the  reforms  focus  on  areas  where  there  is  political  will, 
and  some  measure  of  capacity.  Third,  DOF  and  OMB’s  reform 
programs  are  strongly  supported  by  technical  support  from  key 
donors  such  as  the  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development (USAID), which is supporting reforms at the BIR and 
BOC;  the  European  Union  (EU),  which  is  providing  assistance  to 
the  OBM;  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development 
(AusAID), which is supporting reforms at the Commission of Audit; 
and the World Bank, which is assisting the DOF and DBM on tax 
administration and expenditure management. 

 
Advisory  TA  will  be  provided  with  the  DPSP.  The  TA  is  estimated  to 
cost $1.15 million equivalent. ADB will finance $800,000 to be financed 
on a grant basis by the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF). 
 
The  TA  will  support  NEDA,  DBM,  DOF,  and  the  Department  of  Trade 
and Industry (DTI) to implement and monitor key policy reforms, and in 
particular to broaden and deepen the investment policy reform agenda 
during  the  DPSP  period.  The  TA  will  have  three  components.  Under 
component  1,  it  will  carry  out  a  provincial  competitiveness  survey  of 
businesses and construct a provincial competitiveness index to help the 
Government to monitor the impact of reforms, identify emerging issues 
affecting  the  investment  climate,  and  track  progress  in  economic 
governance  in  the  provinces.  Under  component  2,  it  will  strengthen 
analytical support and capacity for the Government’s efforts to facilitate 
private  sector  development  in  the  services  sector,  with  a  focus  on 
emerging  growth  sectors  in  the  domestic  distribution  sector.  Under 
component  3,  it  will  support  efforts  by  NEDA,  DBM,  DOF,  and  DTI  to 
improve  competitiveness  through  further  policy  reforms  including 
investment  incentives,  trade  policy  and  institutions,  and  business  red 
tape and regulatory reform.

Assistance 

 
 
 

 

   

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
program  cluster  for  the  Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP)  comprising  three 
subprograms, and (ii) a proposed loan to the Republic of the Philippines for subprogram 1 of the 
DPSP.  The  DPSP  supports  a  common  policy  reform  program  prepared  by  a  joint  team  of 
representatives of the Government of the Philippines, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and 
the World Bank. This report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for improving the 
investment climate and business competitiveness and, if the Board approves the proposed loan, 
I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will  approve  the  TA.  The  program 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM AND MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

A. 

Development Strategies and the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan  

In  2004,  the  Government  announced  a  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan 
2. 
(MTPDP),  1  2004–2010  setting  out  the  country’s  development  priorities,  policy  agenda, 
programs,  and  projects  for  the  next  6  years.  The  MTPDP  was  a  departure  from  the  previous 
sector-based  approach.  A  heavy  emphasis  was  laid  on  targets  and  outcomes,  and  all 
government agency activities (including projects) in all sectors were prioritized according to their 
potential  contribution  to  outcomes.  To  improve  operational  efficiency,  agencies  were  to  be 
streamlined to deliver core functions according to their mandated outcomes.  
 
The key objectives of the MTPDP are to achieve higher and more sustainable economic 
3. 
growth,  create  jobs,  reduce  poverty,  and  make  progress  toward  the  Millennium  Development 
Goals  (MDGs).    Structured  around  the  President’s  Ten-Point  Legacy  Agenda, 2 the  MTPDP 
focuses on five core areas: (i) economic growth and job creation; (ii) energy independence and 
power sector reforms; (iii) social justice and basic needs; (iv) education and youth opportunities; 
and (v) anticorruption and governance activities (Figure 1). It identifies the major challenges as:  
the fiscal imbalance; inadequate infrastructure; rapid urbanization and congestion, especially in 
Metro Manila; increasing unemployment; and inefficient delivery of basic services.    
 
4. 
In  2005,  the  Government  and  its  international  development  partners  converted  the 
annual consultative group meetings into the Philippines Development Forum (PDF). 3 The PDF 
provides an opportunity for an ongoing dialogue with other stakeholders from civil  society, the 
private sector, and the academic community. The Government convenes the PDF to discuss the 
reform  agenda  and  the  ways  donors  can  assist  implementation.  The  PDF  allows  the 
development partners to enhance their policy engagement with the Government and to provide 
an impetus to the implementation of the MTPDP. Currently the PDF has seven working groups, 
each  focusing  on  priority  areas  of  the  Government’s  development  agenda:  (i)  economic  and 
fiscal  reforms;  (ii) governance  and  anticorruption  activities;  (iii)  growth  and  investment; 
(iv) MDGs and social progress; (v) decentralization and local government; (vi) sustainable rural 
development; and (vii) Mindanao. In March 2006, the Government agreed with the World Bank 
to use the PDF agenda as the basis for a World Bank development policy loan (DPL). Shortly 
after the workshop, ADB was invited to join the process and to jointly prepare the reform agenda

through  the  DPSP.  The  DPSP  will  anchor  and  track  progress  in  four  core  areas  of  the  PDF: 
fiscal consolidation; governance; investment climate and infrastructure; and social progress.

B. 

The Government and its Development Partners 

5. 
The  proposed  Development  Policy  Support  Program  loans  will  support  the  broad 
priorities of the Government’s agenda, as highlighted in the development policy letter addressed 
to  the  President  of  ADB  (Appendix  2).  These  broad  areas  include  (i)  fiscal  consolidation, 
macroeconomic  stability,  and  creditworthiness;  (ii) governance  and  anticorruption  policies;  (iii) 
the  investment  climate  and  infrastructure;  and  (iv) social  inclusion  (Figure  2).  The  close 
alignment  between  its  own  reform  agenda  and  the  DPSP  will  strengthen  the  Government’s 
commitment to the reforms under the DPSP.  
 

 
 

 
 

 

  

3

The  Medium-Term  Programmatic  Approach.  The  World  Bank’s  country  assistance 
6. 
strategy (CAS)4 lays out the rationale for a series of development policy loans (DPLs), subject to 
progress  in  fiscal  consolidation,  governance,  and  the  investment  climate.  ADB’s  country 
strategy  and  program  (CSP)  2005-2007,5 indicated  that  ADB  would  consider  cofinancing  the 
proposed single tranche development policy loan contemplated by the World Bank in its CAS, 
subject  to  continued  progress  in  fiscal  reforms  by  the  Government.6   The  Government  is  on 
track to meet the CSP’s fiscal targets of a national government budget deficit of 1.4% of GDP by 
2007  (currently  the  deficit  is  estimated  to  be  about  1.8%  for  2006),  and  a  reduction  in  the 
consolidated  public  sector  (CPSD)  budget  deficit  by  10%  per  annum  from  the  2004  baseline 
deficit of 4.8% of GDP (the CPSD is currently about 2%).  
 
7. 
The  proposed  DPSP  cluster  provides  (i)  a  coherent  reform  strategy  with  discrete  but 
linked three subprograms; (ii) a strong emphasis on performance, as the decision on whether to 
proceed with the next subprogram is contingent on satisfactory performance of the triggers; and 
(iii)  flexibility  in  the  reform  measures,  with  provisions  for  incorporating  lessons  learned  and 
responding to changes in the external environment in the design of downstream subprograms. 
The  proposed  DPSP  for  the  Philippines  is  modeled  on  a  similar  ADB  program  for  Indonesia,7 
which is also jointly financed by a World Bank development policy loan. The key features of the 
Indonesia DPSP include (i) a series of single tranche operations, with a well-defined, medium-
term  framework  specified  at  the  outset  and  including  completed  high-impact  reforms  prior  to 
Board  consideration;  (ii)  triggers  for  subsequent  subprograms  so  as  to  ensure  a  continuous 
dialogue  between  the  Government,  development  partners,  and  stakeholders;  and  (iii)  a  small 
number  of  well-targeted  policy  actions  designed  to  achieve  high-impact  outcomes  in  priority 
sectors.   
 
8. 
Subprogram 1 of the Philippines DPSP will be financed by ADB ($250 million) and the 
World  Bank’s  DPL  ($250  million).  The  World  Bank’s  DPL  was  approved  by  its  Board  on  14 
December  2006,  while  ADB’s  DPSP  is  scheduled  for  Board  consideration  in  February  2007. 
Subprogram  1  focuses  on  fiscal  consolidation  and  enhanced  governance  in  public  sector 
financial management and will create the basis for continuous policy dialogue and engagement 
over the period 2007–2009.  
 
Subprogram 2 will continue the momentum of the reforms in subprogram 1, and will be 
9. 
financed  by  the  ADB  and  the  World  Bank.  In  addition  to  continuing  fiscal  consolidation, 
subprogram  2  will  support  the  Government’s  governance  agenda  in  key  government  revenue-
collecting  agencies  under  the  Department  of  Finance  (DOF),  and  expenditure  management 
under the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and selected line ministries covering 
infrastructure  and  social  sectors.  Subprogram  2  will  increase  the  focus  on  improving  the 
investment  climate,  laying  the  groundwork  for  a  more  substantial  reform  agenda  in  2008.  In 
addition, it will address key risks identified in subprogram 1.  
 
10. 
 Building on reforms under subprogram 2, subprogram 3 is expected in 2008, and will be 
financed  by  ADB  and  the  World  Bank.  Subprogram  3  will  continue  to  focus  on  fiscal 
consolidation and governance, but there will be a stronger focus on enhancing the investment 
climate, improving infrastructure, delivering social services, and making progress in other areas

that  addresses  thematic  and  cross-cutting  issues  of  fiscal  sustainability,  governance  and  anti-

leaves  the  detail  of  the  policy  reforms  to  programs  such  as  the  power  sector  development 
program8 and the financial market regulation and intermediation program.9  
 
14. 
The ADB’s DPSP and its support for coordinated sector-specific interventions are part of 
efforts  to  align  and  harmonize  the  strategies  of  development  partners  with  those  of  the 
Government.  The  DPSP  and  the  parallel  policy  dialogue  on  sector  reforms  has  been  greatly 
appreciated by the Government.

THE SECTOR 

III. 

 

A. 

Review of the Economy, Investment Climate and Poverty 

III. 

THE SECTOR 

15. 
Sustained  Macroeconomic  Performance  in  2006.  The  Philippine  economy  ended 
2005 with overall annual real gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 5%. This was down from 
6.2% in 2004, but above the average growth rate of 4.3% per annum from 1990 to 2005. Table 
1  presents  data  on  key  indicators  over  2003–2006  to  show  the  recovery  and  restoration  of 
macroeconomic stability since 2004. The economy expanded by 5.4% in the first three quarters 
of  2006.  Services  have  been  the  fastest  growing  sector  with  an  average  growth  rate  of  6.7% 
since  2003,  contributing  to  almost  60%  of  economic  growth,  followed  by  manufacturing  and 
utilities. On the demand side, consumption spending contributed to 70–80% of economic growth, 
followed  by  a  recent  surge  in  exports.  The  upturn  in  the  economy  in  2006,  despite  higher  oil 

 

 

  

 

6 
 

prices, indicates the Philippine economy is becoming more resilient, and has not been matched 
by its Asian neighbors. However, the investment rate has declined since 2003, although it may 
have  bottomed  out  in  2005.  Inflation  accelerated  in  2004  to  peak  at  8.6%  at  the  end  of  2004, 
falling  to  6.6%  in  December  2005.  Inflation  jumped  a  little  after  the  value  added  tax  (VAT) 
increase  in  February  2006,  but  has  since  declined  and  annual  inflation  reached  4.7%  in 
November (year-on-year). NEDA estimates year-end inflation in the range of 5.2–5.7% for 2006. 
Prudent monetary management has helped reduce inflation and consequently domestic interest 
rates  continue  to  inch  down.  The  91-day  Treasury  bill  rate  averaged  5.6%  in  2006,  compared 
with 5.9% in 2005 and 7.6% in 2004. Record inflows of remittances have contributed to a higher 
current  account  surplus,  which  in  turn  has  helped  to  stabilize  household  consumption  against 
the backdrop of higher oil prices and VAT increases.

Returning  Confidence  in  the  Philippine  Economy. The improved fiscal situation and 
16. 
robust economic growth has begun to shift investor perceptions about the medium-term outlook 
for  the  Philippine  economy.  Sovereign  borrowing  costs  have  fallen,  with  spreads  on 
Government bonds denominated in US dollars cut in half in 2006 from 2004 levels. There has 
been  an  increase  in  capital  flows,  and  the  Philippine  peso  has  appreciated  by  about  6.7% 
against the US dollar since the start of the year, and has averaged about P50.8 to US$1 in the 
last 5 months of 2006. All three major international rating agencies have improved their outlooks 
for the Philippine economy. Fitch and Standard & Poor’s improved their outlooks for Philippine 
sovereign credit from negative to stable in early 2006, followed by Moody’s, which upgraded its 
negative outlook to stable in October. However, these ratings are still two levels from investment 
grade  (Fitch),  three  levels  from  investment  grade  (Standard  &  Poor’s),  and  four  levels  from 
investment grade (Moody’s).  
 
17. 
Turnaround  in  the  Government’s  Fiscal  Management.  After  implementing  several 
difficult tax and fiscal measures, the consolidated public sector (CPSD) deficit as a share of the 
gross domestic product (GDP) declined from a peak of 5.2% in 2003 to an estimated 1.8% in 
2006,  aided  by  a  better-than-expected  fall  in  the  National  Government  (NG)  budget  deficit—
estimated at 1.8% of GDP in 2006, well below its programmed target deficit of 2.1%. The fiscal 
deficit  through  to  November  2006  is  estimated  at  P58  billion,  half  the  deficit  level  during  the 
same period in 2005.10 Tax revenues have performed strongly in 2006 to date, growing by 19% 
through  October  (year  on  year),  with  VAT  revenues  growing  by  64%.  Overall,  tax  revenues 
looked set to rise by about 1% of GDP in 2006, the first increase of any significance in a decade.  
 
18.  Modest Formal Employment Growth. About an average of 650,000 jobs were created 
in the first 10 months of 2006 or a growth rate of 2% over the 2005 level.  Formal employment 
grew by an average of 1.5% and informal employment expanded by 2.5%. Moreover, the growth 
has not been sufficient to more than offset increases in the labor force. Consequently, the youth 
unemployment  rate  remains  persistently  high  at  18.7%.  While  current  economic  growth  rates 
explain part of the insufficient job creation in the formal sector, restrictive labor regulations have 
also contributed to the persistence of unemployment, in particular youth unemployment. Based 
on ADB staff estimates, economic growth of about 6–7% per annum over the next 4 years will 
be  required  to  create  close  to  the  government’s  target  of  4 million  new  jobs  by  2010.  The 
challenge for the Government will be to increase investment rates well above the current 15% of 
GDP to achieve higher and more sustainable economic growth over the longer term.  
   
19. 
Progress in Reducing Poverty. The most recent family income and expenditure survey 
(FIES)11 indicated that poverty had declined from 33% in 2000 to 30% in 2003, based on daily 
caloric  intake.  Poverty  incidence  based  on  the  $2  a  day  poverty  measure  also  declined  from 
46.7%  in  2000  to  41.9%  in  2005.  Real  per  capita  incomes  have  increased  across  all  income 
groups, with the poorest groups experiencing a real increase of 10% between 2000 and 2003. 
With  per  capita  GDP  growing  2.9%  to  4.0%  per  year  since  2004,  and  with  large  inflows  of 
remittances,  further  declines  in  the  poverty  rate  can  be  expected,  but  these  need  to  be 
accelerated.

B. 

Issues and Opportunities   

1. 

Fiscal Consolidation and Macroeconomic Stability 

Tax Revenue Effort. After improving in the first half of the 1990s, the Philippines’ fiscal 
20.  
fortunes  quickly  reversed  following  the  Asian  crisis.  In  the  mid-1990s,  budget  revenues 
increased  markedly  and  the  CPSD  budget  was  almost  balanced.  Public  debt  was  on  a  clear 
declining path. Fiscal reforms in the late 1980s to mid-1990s—including the introduction of VAT 
in 1988—helped to improve fiscal sustainability in the mid-1990s. Then came the Asian crisis, 
tax revenues plunged, the CPSD deficit increased sharply and public debt began to climb (see 
Figure 3). The fiscal position of the Philippines in the 1990s was adversely affected by: (i) the 
fact  that  important  sectors,  including  energy,  were  exempted  from  VAT;  (ii)  the  erosion  of  the 
income  tax  base  caused  by  the  proliferation  of  tax  incentives  in  new  growth  sectors  of  the 
economy;  and  (iii)  persistently  weak  tax  administration.  These  policies  were  maintained  for 
several  years  after  the  crisis,  and,   combined a   with  deterioration  in  governance  and  tax 
administration efforts in the revenue collecting agencies, caused  a further deterioration in the 
fiscal  position.  Recent  fiscal  measures  (including  a  broadening  of  the  tax  base,  elimination  of 
exemptions  from VAT, an increase in excise  taxes, improvements in tax administration, and a 
reduction  in  unproductive  spending)  have  helped  address  the  problem  of  fiscal  sustainability. 
The  Government  has  therefore  advanced  its  target  of  a  balanced  budget  from  2010  to  2008. 
Additional  reforms  in  taxation,  rationalization  of  fiscal  incentives,  improving  management 
performance  of  government  owned  and  controlled  corporations 
tax 
administration (such as cleaning, updating and expanding the tax registration database) will be 
necessary  to  achieve  this  target  and  ensure  the  fiscal  adjustment  is  sustainable.  International 
comparisons  of  tax  revenue  to  GDP  ratios  suggest  that  there  is  much  upside  potential  for 
improving tax revenue performance in the Philippines (Appendix 4).

Expenditure  Management.  Fiscal  sustainability  also  requires  reforms  on 
expenditure  side.  A  well  functioning  budget  and  financial  management  system  comprises  of 
three core elements. First, a medium-term framework in budgeting that aligns allocations more 
explicitly  to  the  government’s  policy  priorities.  The  second  element  is  a  performance-based 
management system to ensure operational efficiency at the government agency level. Finally, a 

 

18

17

16

15

14

13

12

11

10

 

  

9

financial  management  information  system  to  ensure  budget  transparency.    In  the  Philippines, 
recent  reports  and  audits  have  highlighted  several  critical  weaknesses  in  expenditure 
management, resulting in poor expenditure allocation and control, wastage, and unpredictability 
of  funds  for  long-term  priority  programs.  These  weaknesses  include:  (i)  a  lack  of  consistency 
between  the  ambitious  (and  extensive)  planning  process  and  the  composition  of  the  budget, 
compounded by policy being made continuously throughout the budget cycle; (ii) the practice of 
incremental budgeting, whereby budget allocations increase incrementally for similar programs 
and projects; and (iii) an inadequate framework for performance-based budgeting in government 
departments  and  agencies.    Moreover,  there  needs  to  be  a  rebalancing  of  the  composition  of 
Government  budget  expenditures.  Budget  allocations  are  biased  toward  statutory  expenditure 
outlays—government  wages,  transfers  to  LGUs,  interest  payments—over  spending  on 
infrastructure,  maintenance  and  social  sectors.  Statutory  outlays  as  a  percentage  of  total 
Government expenditure went up by over 11 percentage points to 75% in 2005 from the 1990 
level. This marked change in expenditure composition led to less flexible budgets, which limited 
discretionary  expenditure  policy  to  cuts  in  spending  on  capital  projects,  maintenance,  and  the 
education  and  health  sectors  (Figure  6).  The  intention  of  the  government  to  allocate  a 
substantial proportion of VAT revenues to priority sectors in the 2006 and 2007 budgets was a 
step  in  the  right  direction.  The  Government  is  addressing  these  expenditure  management 
issues  through  the  Medium-Term  Expenditure  Framework  (MTEF),  which  links  annual 
budgeting  decisions  to  medium-term  spending  constraints  and  contains  a  3-year  rolling 
projection  (or  forward  estimates)  of  expenditure  requirements  of  approved  programs  and 
projects.  The  MTEF  has  been  only  partially  implemented  (e.g.,  no  budget  ceilings  have  been 
imposed)  and  the  pace  of  implementation  has  been  slow  (it  is  being  implemented  in  only  two 
departments  although  it  was  first  introduced  in  2001).  It  is  important  that  the  MTEF  be  fully 
implemented  and  expanded  across  all  national  agencies  to  improve  the  budget  planning 
process and impose fiscal discipline.  
 
22. 
Debt  Management.  Debt  management  policy  needs  to  be  stronger  to  ensure  debt 
sustainability  over  the  long  term,  including  addressing  contingent  liabilities.  Debt  sustainability 
assessments indicate that there is a need to improve management of the risks of existing debt 
and 
in  such 
macroeconomic  variables  as  GDP  growth,  interest  rates,  and  exchange  rates.  Some  progress 
has  been  made  in  debt  management  in  recent  years,  particularly  in  lengthening  the  average 
maturity of government debt and in maintaining a diverse portfolio of obligations. However, this 
progress  needs  to  be  extended  to  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  the  budget  and  economy  to 
macroeconomic  fluctuations.  The  growing  stock  of  debt  outside  the  Government’s  own 
borrowing  program,  such  as  that  of  GOCCs  and  government  financial  institutions  (GFIs),  and 
the challenge of accurately quantifying and assessing the level of contingent liabilities, as well 
as  the  assets  of  GOCCs,  add  to  the  risks.  An  ongoing  ADB  TA  project  aims  to  improving  the 
national  debt  and  risk  management  function  and  establish  a  process  of  more  effective 
monitoring and coordination of debt and risk management functions. The TA project is expected 
to be completed by June 2007.12

The  wide  dissemination  of  the  Government’s  electronic  procurement  system 
(PhilGEPS)  and  the  implementing  rules  to  the  2003  Government  Procurement

25. 
These  early  successes  in  good  governance  and  fighting  corruption  have  not  yet 
translated  into  positive  changes  of  perception  by  the  wider  audience.  To  some  extent  the 
ongoing high-profile corruption cases have clouded perceptions about the Government’s recent 
innovative initiatives to strengthen governance. The persistent perceptions of poor performance 
in this area also indicate the challenges the Government faces if it is to create credibility in its 
governance  strategy.  Therefore,  it  will  be  important  for  the  Government  to  make  significant 
progress in governance initiatives in its revenue and expenditure management program.  
 
26. 
Information  Management  Systems.  Much  more  needs  to  be  done  to  improve 
governance in public expenditure management and to control corruption, in particular to ensure 
that the medium-term expenditure framework is  implemented at government agencies, so that 
systems  and  processes  for  allocating  and  executing  budgetary  resources  become  more 
transparent  and  efficient.  It  will  be  important  to  support  implementation  of  the  MTEF  through 
measures  that  increase  transparency  and  accountability  and  thus  reduce  the  scope  for  undue 
discretion  in  budget  execution.  This  will  require  greater  disclosure  of  budget  releases  and 
disbursements in a format that allow DBM, the private sector and civil society to easily track and 
match realized expenditures of line agencies with budget allocations. The Department of Budget 
and  Management  has  introduced  measures  to  improve  transparency  and  efficiency  in  the 
budgeting  process,  including  taking  initial  steps  to  develop  an  integrated  government  financial 
management  information  system  (GFMIS).  It  will  be  important  to  complete  the  design  and 
development of the GFMIS to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the services and to 
improve transparency.  
 
27. 
Procurement.  Procurement  is  an  important  area  where  increased  competition, 
transparency, and monitoring have the potential to enhance the cost-efficiency of resource use 
and to improve governance. The Government Procurement Reform Act, 2003, consolidated all 
rules  of  public  procurement;  mandated  the  use  of  the  electronic  government  procurement 
system,  PhilGEPS;  and  required  the  participation  of  private  and  nongovernment  organization 
(NGO)  observers  in  the  procurement  process.  The  act  is  a  significant  step  in  streamlining 
procurement rules and regulations to enhance transparency and accountability.  In addition, the 
reforms  have  meant  there  has  been  a  gradual  convergence  between  Philippine  procurement 
systems  and  international  standards.  Philippine  systems  are  becoming  more  like  the 
frameworks  already  used  by  the  country’s  large  multilateral  partners.17 The  implementation  of 
the  Procurement  Reform  Act  resulted  in  savings  estimated  at  P400  million  in  2005  and  has 
contributed  to  a  50%  reduction  in  the  cost  of  textbooks  since  2000. 18 However,  anecdotal 
evidence  shows  there  are  still  huge  leaks  in  government  spending  due  to  corruption  in 
procurement, in part due to inadequate public disclosure of procurement transactions, and weak 
enforcement  of  procurement  rules  and  procedures.  Therefore,  it  will  be  important  to  continue 
with reforms implementing the Procurement Reform Act to enhance the capacity of government

Civil Service. Civil service reform is another important area with the potential to improve 
28. 
public  sector  efficiency.  The  Philippine  bureaucracy  is  administratively  overstretched  and  this 
makes  institutionalizing  much-needed  reforms  extremely  difficult.  There  is  duplication  and 
overlapping of programs and activities, uncoordinated policy and program implementation, poor 
sector management, wasteful use of resources, and excessive red tape. Public service delivery 
is  constrained  by  a  lack  of  qualified  personnel  and  uncompetitive  compensation  levels.  In 
addition,  DBM,  the  Civil  Service  Commission  (CSC),  and  the  Government  Service  Insurance 
System (GSIS) currently maintain their own personnel databases and this makes it difficult for 
human resource management and planning. Given fiscal constraints, it is clear that the size and 
cost  of  the  civil  service  requires  review  and  adjustment,  including  (i)  establishing  an  effective 
system  to  control  employment  and  the  wage  bill,  (ii)  increasing  transparency  and  the 
competitiveness of civil service compensation and (iii) clarifying, designing and implementing a 
strategy for adjusting the core missions, functions and structure of government agencies along 
with budget and administrative structural reforms. The Government has drafted a compensation 
bill  that  aims  to  rationalize  and  standardize  the  salaries  of  civil  servants  at  all  levels  of  the 
government  and  to  bring  salary  scales  into  line  with  those  in  the  private  sector  to  attract  and 
retain  highly  qualified  staff.  The  bill  has  been  submitted  to  Congress.    Supporting  reforms  to 
integrate civil service personnel databases will also be needed.  
 

3. 

Investment Climate and Infrastructure 

29. 
The  Private  Sector.  After  rapidly  expanding  in  the  first  half  of  the  1990s,  investment 
growth  in  the  Philippines  slumped  following  the  Asian  crisis  and  has  been  slow  to  recover,  a 
characteristic shared with all the other crisis-hit countries since 1998 (Figure 4). The Philippines 
was  investing  the  equivalent  of  25%  of  its  GDP  before  the  crisis  but  this  has  now  declined  to 
15%. Lost investments have been translated into lost growth, and in turn to slow creation of jobs 
and  poverty  reduction.  The  decline  in  investment  covers  both  private  and  public  investments. 
The average annual infrastructure spending between 2001 and 2005 was 2.4% of GDP, which 
was  low  compared  with  that  in  other  countries  in  the  region,  and  well  below  pre-crisis  levels 
(when it approached 8%). While there are tentative signs of a weak investment recovery in 2006, 
this  has  been  much  slower  than  in  some  of  the  comparable  economies  in  the  region  (e.g., 
Thailand since 2002 and Indonesia since 2004).

30. 
A  critical  challenge  facing  the  Philippines  is  how  to  increase  investment  significantly  in 
the medium term. The Government will need to implement measures in a number of areas such 
as improving the investment climate, and establishing a transparent framework for infrastructure 
development, including improving the resource efficiency of public infrastructure spending as a 
corollary to fiscal consolidation efforts. 
 
31. 
Businesses  Constraints  and  Unfavorable  Perceptions  of  the  Investment  Climate. 
The ADB-World Bank Investment Climate Survey (footnote 11) in 2003 reported several major 
constraints in the Philippines, including macroeconomic instability, followed by corruption, high 
electricity rates, policy uncertainty, tax administration, and anticompetitive practices (Figure 5). 
According to the IFC Doing Business Report for 2006,19 it takes 11 steps to launch a business 
and about 48 days to carry them out in the Philippines (in Malaysia it takes 30 days, Thailand 33 
days, Viet Nam 50 days, and Indonesia 97 days). A recent Social Weather Survey (footnote 13) 
of businesses suggests that investor perceptions about red tape and associated corruption have 
deteriorated  recently,  with  Philippine  businesses  experiencing  increased  difficulties  with  red 
tape  at  the  Land  Transportation  Office,  Department  of  Agriculture  (DA),  and  BOC.    The 
investment  incentives  framework  is  complicated,  involving  several  administering  agencies  and 
64  different  laws  on  incentives.  Consequently  the  framework  has  become  cumbersome  and 
uncoordinated  with  the  national  economic  strategy.  Moreover,  it  has  encouraged  widespread 
revenue leakage as some of the incentives are redundant. The Government is looking at ways 
to  rationalize  the  investment  incentives  regime  and  a  rationalization  of  fiscal  incentives  bill  is 
pending  in  Congress.  The  incentives  framework  must  be  streamlined  and  its  administration 
improved to minimize revenue leakage.

32. 
Inadequate Infrastructure, Especially Roads. Roads and inter-island shipping account 
for almost all freight and passenger traffic.  While the road sector has made some progress in 
the  past  few  years,  high  levels  of  congestion,  the  poor  condition  of  large  portions  of  the  road 
network, inadequate connectivity, and the lack of a sustainable road safety strategy reduce the 
efficiency of the road network. As a result, for example, inter-city freight rates in the Philippines 
are more than 50% higher than those in Thailand or Viet Nam. Chronic underinvestment in the 
national  road  network  is  a  characteristic  of  budgetary  stress  and  unresponsive  investment 
choices.  The  Government  has  since  increased  funds  allocated  to  road  maintenance  due  to 
rising contributions from road users in a Special Road Fund. But these are still only about one 
third  of  the  estimated  needs,  and  plans  for  achieving  full  cost  recovery  have  been  lagging. 
Private  sector  investment  has  been  low  and  has  declined  in  recent  years  because  of  an 
uncertain  investment  climate,  a  poor  legal  environment,  and  land  acquisition  problems. 
Investors  are  concerned  about  the  policy,  legal  and  regulatory  distortions  in  the  infrastructure 
sector,  and  face  significant  legal  risks  as  recourse  to  the  judicial  system  is  protracted  and 
uncertain. Weaknesses in the Build-Operate-and-Transfer (BOT) Law, and the policy framework 
for  public–private  partnerships

departments  also  adversely  affects  infrastructure  investment.  The  government  is  taking  some 
measures to make road sector more viable for the private sector. For example it is increasingly 
contracting  out  road  maintenance  to  the  private  sector,  whereby  its  share  would  grow  from 
about 50% in 2005 to 70% in 2007 and 100% by 2009.

4. 

Social Inclusion 

34. 
Social  Sectors’  Declining  Share  of  the  Budget  Since  1999.  Recent  fiscal  austerity 
measures  to  reduce  the  Government  deficit  have  disproportionately  hurt  social  policy 
expenditures.  This  means  the  Philippines  may  have  difficulty  meeting  some  of  its  Millennium 
Development Goal (MDG) targets, particularly those in education and health (Figure 6). Weak 
governance  and  inequality  in  resource  allocation  have  also  contributed  to  poor  social  sector 
outcomes.

35.  MDG Targets. The Philippines is on track to meet several Millennium Development Goal 
(MDG)  targets,  including  the  target  for  reducing  extreme  poverty,  but  is  at  risk  of  not  meeting 
MDG target of universal primary education by 2015. While high school participation rates have 
increased  from  58%  in  2001/02  to  60%  in  2003/04,  elementary  participation  rates  have  fallen 
from  97%  in  1999/00  to  88.4%  in  2003/04.  The  impact  of  the  adverse  fiscal  position  on  the 
sector  has  been  exacerbated  by  rapid  population  growth  and  consequently  real  government 
spending per student has fallen by an average of 3% per annum from 2000 to 2004.  
 
36. 
There is also a risk that the Philippines may not meet the MDG targets for reducing child 
malnutrition  and  maternal  mortality,  although  it  is  on  track  to  achieve  the  targets  for  reducing 
child mortality, controlling communicable diseases, and increasing access to water.  Low health 
service  quality  and  problems  of  financial  and  physical  access  for  the  poor  lie  behind  this  poor 
performance.    Public  spending  on  health  (US$14  per  capita  per  year,  for  national,  local 
government  and  social  health  insurance  spending  combined)  and  total  spending  (US$33  per

capita per year, and 3.1% of GDP) on health in the Philippines are low for a country at its level 
of economic development, and have remained static for the past 8 years. This has resulted in

37. 
The Government is well aware of these problems and is committed to improving quality 
and access to basic education and health care, reversing recent declines in performance.  The 
2007  budget  allocates  substantial  real  increases  to  the  social  sector  (12%  over  the  adjusted 
2006  budget).  The  larger  share  for  the  DepED  is  to  increase  provisions  for  the  public  school 
system  and  proved  larger  allocations  for  teacher  recruitment,  textbooks,  school  buildings  and 
repair and maintenance of schools, so as to widen coverage and improve quality.  In the health 
sector,  with  support  from  ADB’s  health  sector  development  program,  the  Government  has 
adopted a sector reform strategy and implementation plans to increase equity, sustainability and 
quality in the health system, particularly in health services that are critical for the poor and for 
the  achievement  of  the  health-related  MDGs. 21  The  proposed  2007  budget  allocates  real 
increases  for  subsidies  for  the  health  insurance  contributions,  which  will  help  to  expand 
enrollment of poor families under the National Health Insurance Program (NHIP).  A program to 
widen  the  access  of  the  poor  to  low-cost  medicines  through  the  Botika  ng  Barangay  will  also 
benefit.    The  Department  of  Health,  in  collaboration  with  the  Philippines  Health  Insurance 
Corporation  and  selected  local  government  units  (LGUs),  will  work  to  make  increases  in 
PhilHealth  enrollment  sustainable,  and  take  measures  to  reduce  the  exclusion  of  some  poor 
from  the  PhilHealth  indigent  program  (and  the  use  of  the  services  by  the    non-poor).  In  this 
regard, improving governance in expenditure management in the social sectors will be important 
to prepare the ground for increased availability of resources as a result of fiscal consolidation. 
 
38.  Medium-term  Strategy  for  Social  Welfare  and  Protection. The Government’s policy 
agenda  for  social  welfare  and  protection  is  at  an  earlier  stage  of  development  than  the 
education and health strategies. The Department of Social Welfare and Development plans to 
develop  a  social  welfare  and  protection  reform  strategy  during  the  period  of  the  DPSP,  and  a 
medium-term  expenditure  framework  for  social  welfare,  protection  and  development.    The 
Government is encouraging LGUs to plan and monitor local poverty reduction strategies, and to 
improve the targeting of services and programs for the poor.  The Department of Social Welfare 
and  Development  (DSWD)  plans  to  review  social  expenditure  for  a  range  of  social  assistance 
programs,  including  cash  and  in-kind  transfer  programs,  and  to  undertake  an  impact 
assessment  of  some  of  its  major  anti-poverty  programs,  including  the  Self-Employment 
Assistance  Kaunlaran  (SEA-K)  and  the  poverty-targeted  KALAHI-CIDSS  community-driven 
development program.    
 
39. 
Community-based  Mapping  System.  The  data  for  local  planning,  monitoring  and 
targeting  pro-poor  programs  are  limited  and  national  poverty  statistics  are  not  sufficiently 
disaggregated  or  timely.  The  lack  of  data  has  been  a  critical  obstacle  to  developing  and 
monitoring  the  effectiveness  of  pro-poor  programs  in  the  past.  To  address  this  gap,  the 
Government  is  advocating  the  use  of  community-based  poverty  mapping  (CBMS)  and  is 
promoting  adoption  of  a  standard  CBMS  by  LGUs  for  pro-poor  planning,  poverty  profiling  and 
monitoring,  and  program  targeting.  Currently,  about  10%  of  LGUs  are  using  the  CBMS,  and 
during the next 3 years, the government plans to support greater use of CBMS by LGUs.  The 
Government anticipates that about half of LGUs will be using CBMS in 2009.

C. 

Lessons  

40. 
ADB  has  supported  reforms  in  several  areas  related  to  macroeconomic  stability 
(covering  such  areas  as  capital  markets  and  the  nonbank  financial  sector)  and  private  sector 
development (transport, energy, and water) and has maintained an ongoing policy dialogue with 
the  Government.  The  ADB  private  sector  assessment22 noted  that  ADB’s  public  and  private 
sector  operations  in  the  Philippines  have  produced  mixed  results  over  the  years.  This  mixed 
performance in operations provides some important lessons for policy lending. 23 These include 
the following.  
 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

Political and macroeconomic stability is a critical factor behind the success of a 
development assistance program. 
Success requires careful program preparation, involving detailed analytical work 
and active consultations with stakeholders. 
Program  designs  should  be  relatively  simple.  Program  designs  that  are  too 
complex and impose excessive demands on the administrative capacities of the 
implementing agencies are likely to fail. 
Sustaining development impact requires close monitoring during implementation. 
This  also  requires  precise  and  clear  measurable  indicators.  The  Philippine 
experience  strongly  suggests  that  the  quality  of  program  monitoring  is  an 
important factor for success. 
The  success  of  the  assistance  program  depends  on  its  ability  to  nurture 
institutional development. Weak institutions have often been cited as one of the  
principal causes  of  project  failures  in  the  Philippines.  For  effective  development 
results, the policy agenda needs to be backed by broader public sector reforms 
that  aim  to  address  thematic  and  cross-cutting  issues  of  governance,  public 
financial  management,  procurement,  and  accountability.  The  development 
debate emphasizes strengthening institutions, including policy-making processes, 
capacity  building,  implementation  of  laws  and  policies,  and  improvements  in 
procedures and systems. 

In light of these lessons, evaluation studies increasingly recommend the following steps 

 
41. 
when designing adjustment lending. 24   
 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

The  economic,  social  and  political  environment  in  which  the  reform  agenda  is 
planned  and  the  degree  of  country  commitment,  ownership,  and  readiness 
shown by the Government need to be carefully assessed.  
The development agenda should encompass longer-term economic, social, and 
institutional issues, and include the flexibility to cope with emerging changes and 
institutional problems. 
Broader  stakeholder  participation  is  needed  to  obtain  adequate  buy-in  and 
diminish the influence of vested interests. 

(iv)  Macroeconomic and fiscal stability measures need to reinforce, and be supported 

by, a proper environment for investment, financial management, and governance.

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

A. 

Objective and Scope 

43. 
The  DPSP  cluster  aims  to  support  the  Government  in  its  efforts  to  (i)  achieve  and 
sustain  higher  economic  growth  through  improved  fiscal  sustainability,  public  financial 
management,  and  a  better  investment  climate;  and  (ii)  reduce  poverty  and  unemployment  by 
reorienting  public  expenditures  to  social  policy  and  productive  needs,  and  by  strengthening 
governance in public financial management.  
 
44. 
The DPSP cluster includes a series of policy reforms which underpin the key priorities of 
Philippines’s  medium-term  growth  strategy  and  the  Philippine  Development  Forum.  These 
reforms are designed to accomplish the following results.

Subprogram  1  is  designed  to  be  a  single-tranche  operation  with  a  well-defined

B. 

Policy Framework and Actions 

46. 
Subprogram  1  focuses  on  four  of  the  seven  core  policy  areas  outlined  in  the  PDF: 
(i) improved  fiscal  sustainability,  macroeconomic  stability  and  creditworthiness,  (ii)  improved 
governance  in  public  expenditure  management  and  reduction  in  corruption,  (iii)  strengthening 
the investment climate, and (iv) social inclusion. All 27 policy measures required for subprogram 
1 to begin had been carried out by mid-October 2006. 
  

1. 
 

Subprogram 1 Core Area 1: Improved Fiscal Sustainability, Macroeconomic 
Stability and Creditworthiness 

Subprogram  1  acknowledges  that  the  Philippines  has  made  positive  progress  in  fiscal 
47. 
consolidation since 2004, leading to a reduction in the CPSD deficit from 5.6% in 2002 to 2.0% 
in  2005.  Subprogram  1  will  support  the  Government’s  fiscal  reforms  that  were  undertaken  in 
2006. The Government’s immediate objectives are to eliminate the public sector deficit by 2009 
and to reduce the nonfinancial public sector (NFPS) debt to below 65% of GDP by 2009. The 
following measures were completed before subprogram 1 was presented to the Board. 
 
48. 
Lower  Public  Sector  Deficit. The reduction in the CPSD deficit from 4.8% in 2004 to 
2.0% in 2005, aided by a reduction in the National Government budget deficit from 3.8% in 2004 
to 2.7% in 2005 and projected to fall below the government’s deficit target of 2.1% in 2006 were 
major achievements and contributed significantly to the recent improvement in the Philippines’ 
credit  rating  outlook  from  BB-  negative  to  BB-  stable  or  equivalent.  Corresponding  with  the 
improved fiscal deficit situation, the NFPS debt to GDP ratio fell from 101% of GDP in 2003 to 
87% in 2005. National Government debt fell from 79% of GDP in 2004 to 72% in 2005 and is 
projected to fall below 70% by the end of 2006.  
 
Higher  Tax  Revenues.  Tax  revenue  increased  by  19%  in  2006  (equivalent  to  an 
49.

Government  deficit  in  2006.  The  increase  in  tax  revenues  was  achieved  by  several  important 
tax  reforms,  which  have  also  improved  the  medium-term  sustainability  of  tax  revenues.  The 
following tax reform measures were undertaken:26

2. 

Subprogram  1  Core  Area  2:  Governance  and  Anti-Corruption  in  Public 
Financial Management 

Subprogram  1  acknowledges  the  recent  revenue  enhancement  measures  initiated  by 
51. 
the  DOF  and  the  OBM,  and  the  Government’s  early  successes  in  improving  governance  and 
fighting corruption in the revenue collecting agencies under DOF. These efforts go hand in hand 
with  the  key  Government  objectives  of  (i)  improving  the  quality  of  public  expenditure 
management, (ii) strengthening performance management and enhancing the delivery of public 
services, (iii) reforming procurement, and (iv) reducing corruption in revenue-collecting agencies.  
The  following  measures  toward  achieving  these  objectives  were  completed  prior  to  Board 
consideration of subprogram 1. 
 
52. 
 Reforms to the Budget Process. An important initiative was the implementation of the 
MTEF for the 2007 budget, which was incorporated into the budget call (where DBM requests 
line  agencies  to  submit  their  proposed  budgets  for  the  next  fiscal  year),  based  on  the  budget 
strategy paper and initial forward estimates for 2007–2009. The budget strategy paper (BSP) is 
part of a process that mandates decision makers to confront budget allocation trade-offs at the 
beginning of the budget process and keep in view the strategic priorities set by the government. 
The  MTEF  has  been  formulated  and  implemented  in  the  health  and  education  sectors.  As  a 
result  of  budget  forward  estimates,  more  allocations  will  be  made  for  education,  health,  and 
infrastructure in the 2007 budget. 

53. 
 In  order  to  improve  transparency  in  public  expenditure  management,  the  Government 
has started posting budget releases for priority projects and internal revenue allocations (IRA) of 
LGUs  on  the  DBM  website. 27 This  information  includes  projects  by  location  and  type.  The 
Government is developing an integrated government financial management system (GFMIS) to 
enhance  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  services,  and  to  improve  transparency  and  public 
access to budget information. Some modules of the government financial management system 
have  already  been  developed.  The  DBM  has  introduced  a  web-enabled  e-Budget  System, 
which  has  greatly  improved  budget  administration.  By  computerizing  budget  releases  and 
accountability  reports,  processing  time  has  been  cut,  transparency  enhanced,  and  fraudulent 
documents  detected.  The  DBM  launched  the  Philippine  Government  Electronic  Procurement 
System  (PhilGEPS)  to  provide  both  government  agencies  and  suppliers  with  a  more  open, 
transparent and  competitive  environment.  The  Commission  on  Audit  (COA)  has  developed  an 
electronic  accounting  system,  the  e-NGAS  (based  on  the  National  Government  Accounting 
Systems  [NGAS],  introduced  in  2002),  So  far,  the  e-NGAS  accounting  module  has  been 
installed  in  73  national  government  agencies,  35  LGUs,  and  7  GOCCs.  Gradually,  e-Budget, 
PhilGEPS,  and  e-NGAS  will  be  integrated  into  Government  financial  management  and 
information systems. These initiatives have meant that more budget information is disclosed to 
civil society groups and other interested stakeholders, thus increasing accountability.  The next

21

phase  will  be  the  design  and  implementation  of  a  plan  that  integrates  these  systems  into  the 
GFMIS.   
 
54. 
 Stronger  Public  Sector  Performance  Management.  In  a  further  effort  to  strengthen 
public  sector  performance,  the  DBM  piloted  a  performance-based  budgeting  process  through 
the  adoption  of  an  organizational  performance  indicator  framework  (OPIF).  To  date,  the  DBM 
has worked with 20 departments to identify programs, activities, and programs in line with major 
final  outputs  (MFOs),  directly  supporting  national  and  sectoral  goals.  The  OPIF  requires  the 
agencies to specify their outcomes, MFOs, and performance indicators. The budget is allocated 
in  accordance  with  the  absorptive  capacity  of  the  agencies,  the  implementation  readiness  of 
new  projects,  and  cost-efficiency  considerations.  The  government  has 
incorporated 
implementation of the OPIF in the 2007 budget call. In support of these performance-enhancing 
initiatives,  the  CSC  has  completed  a  government  human  resources  management  information 
system  in  order  to  establish  better control  over  the  level  and  distribution  of  public  sector  staff. 
This  system  has  been  completed  and  will  be  extended  to  the  regions.  The  DBM,  CSC  and 
Government  Service  Insurance  System  (GSIS)  currently  maintain  their  own  personnel 
databases and there is a need to integrate these. A framework linking DBM’s OPIF to the CSC’s 
personnel  rating  system  for  an  integrated  performance  management  system  in  government 
needs to be developed.  
 
55.  More  Public  Disclosure  of  Procurement  Budget  and  Releases.  An  electronic 
procurement  system  (PhilGEPS)  will  be  the  only  portal  for  all  government  procurement 
transactions. The first phase of PhilGEPS was completed in 2006 and has three main features: 
(i)  an  electronic  bulletin  board,  which  posts  all  procurement  opportunities  in  government;  (ii)  a 
supplier and subscriber registry, which is a listing of all contractors who wish to do business with 
government;  and  (iii)  an  electronic  catalogue  listing  common  use  items  that  government 
agencies are required to purchase from the central purchasing agency. Since September 2006, 
PhilGEPS has been made accessible to the general public, with the posting of all bid awards by 
central offices of the targeted departments (DPWH, DOH, DepED, and DA). As a result of these 
new  systems,  there  has  been  a  significant  increase  in  the  number  of  bid  opportunities  and 
awards posted on the PhilGEPS in 2006.28 The number of notices with awards increased from 
3,128 in January to September 2004 to 8,987 during the same period in 2006. The aggregate 
amount of the awards posted went up from P4.4 billion to P21.2 billion.   
  
56. 
Stronger  Anticorruption  Revenue  Programs.  The  number  of  cases  filed  with  the 
Department  of  Justice  are:  65  cases  for  tax  evaders  filed  under  the  RATE  program;  16 
smuggling  cases  filed  under  RATS;  and  43  cases  filed  under  RIPS.  The  DOJ  and  the  BIR 
signed a Memorandum of Agreement creating a task force to expedite these cases.  In addition, 
to  improve  investigation  and  prosecution  of  tax  and  graft  cases,  the  government  has  further 
strengthened the OMB and DOF, and as result increased the conviction rate of cases filed by 
OMB  before  the  anti-corruption  court,  the  Sandiganbayan  (the  conviction  rate  for  cases 
involving  high-ranking  officials  increased  from  24%  in  2004  to  33%  in  2005).  The  OMB  is 
recovering proceeds from corruption. In early 2006, the amount of asset forfeiture petitions filed 
before the Sandiganbayan totaled P700 million. 
 
57. 
Introduction  of  the  Integrity  Development  Review  (IDR).  The  IDR  examines  an 
agency's  practices  and  procedures  for  their  vulnerability  to  corruption  so  an  agency-wide 
anticorruption plan can be developed that reduces the opportunity for corruption. The OMB and 
the Development Academy of the Philippines undertook a review of five selected agencies. So

Subprogram  1  supports  the  Government’s  agenda  to  improve  competitiveness.  The 
main objective is to increase the share of GDP spent on investment and infrastructure. Reform 
areas  of  critical  significance  targeted  under  subprogram  1  include:  (a)  clarifying  and 
strengthening 
facilitating

59.  Measures 
Improve 
Competitiveness.  A  review  in  2006  estimated  the  potential  revenue  losses  from  various 
incentives  and  provided  recommendations  for  streamlining  and  administering  incentives.  The 
Government is considering these recommendations as part of its planning process to streamline 
investment incentives. The Government issued Executive Order (EO) 554, which eliminates the 
fees  and  charges  imposed  on  export  clearances,  inspections,  permits,  certificates,  and  other 
documentation  requirements.  The  elimination  of  fees  and  charges  is  crucially  important  to 
international 
in  exporting  goods, 
reducing 
competitiveness.  EO  554  will  particularly  benefit  small  exporters  and  ADB  estimates  that 
savings  for  exporters  could  amount  to  at  least  $40  million  in  2007.  In  August  2006,  the 
Government  issued  EO  557,  with  established  a  national  task  force  on  reducing  red  tape.  The 
task force is chaired by a representative from the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) and is 
responsible  for  establishing  an  action  plan  for  regulatory  reform.  The  broad  agenda  was 
announced  and  discussed  at  a  DTI-organized  competitiveness  summit  in  October  2006.  The 
task force will coordinate national efforts to reduce the time it takes to start a business and the 
number of permits, the time to obtain them, and the cost required.  
 
60.  Measures  to  Improve  the  Policy  Framework  for  Infrastructure  Investments.  The 
BOT  implementing  rules  and  regulations  committee  (IRR)  revised  the  rules  and  regulations  to 
improve  the  framework  for  infrastructure  investment  and  lay  the  groundwork  for  public–private 
partnerships  in  infrastructure.  One  substantial  change  of  the  BOT  IRR  is  that  project  approval 
has been streamlined. Previously, a project had to undergo two approval stages, which was a 
major source of delay: in both stages—project approval and draft contract approval—depending 
on the amount, approval would have to be sought from the Investment Coordinating Committee  
or NEDA Board. There is now only a single pass to expedite project approval. Also, in the new 
BOT IRR, the “contract re-opener” clause was removed thus eliminating a major source of delay 
in  implementation.    The  current  quality  of  infrastructure  is  a  concern,  and  the  contractors’ 
performance evaluation system (CPES) is a system of grading the performance of a constructor 
for  a  specific  kind  of  infrastructure  project,  using  a  standard  criteria.  The  NEDA  infrastructure 
committee  has  further  developed  the  CPES  guidelines  (CPES)  to  improve  the  quality  of 
infrastructure investments, and their timely completion within the budget. The Government has

The DPSP Medium-Term Program: Triggers for Subprogram 2 

 
C. 
 
62. 
The development policy letter sets out the Government reform agenda for the next 1–2 
years,  building  on  the  reform  momentum  of  subprogram  1.  Triggers  for  the  subprogram  2  are 
described in Appendix 2, Table A2.2. The monitorable milestones for subprogram 2 are listed in 
the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 

1. 

Fiscal Sustainability, Macroeconomic Stability and Creditworthiness 

63. 
Reduction in Public Sector Deficits. There are two fiscal policy triggers for the second 
subprogram.  The  Government  is  committed  to  continue  progress  reducing  the  National 
Government deficit toward 1% of GDP in 2007. The Government will maintain the consolidated 
public sector (CPSD) deficit at 2% in 2006, and on track toward a 1.4% deficit in 2007.  Over the 
medium  term,  the  Government  will  continue  to  initiate  reforms  to  reduce  the  CPSD  deficit  to 
0.5% by the end of 2009 and eliminate the National Government deficit by 2009, and reducing 
the  non-financial  public  sector  (NFPS)  debt  to  65%  of  GDP  by  2009  (baseline  87%  in  2005). 
Over the medium term the Government intends to strengthen its debt management policy so it 
can improve its management of the risk of the existing debt and reduce the vulnerability of the 
budget. Publication of a paper in 2007 outlining the options for the debt management strategy 
will be an important milestone action. Another milestone action in support of fiscal consolidation 
is the development of a strategic and performance management framework for three GOCCs. 
This  framework  would  establish  monitorable  performance  targets  for  the  larger  GOCCs 
consistent with reducing the CPSD deficit.  
 
64. 
Increase  in  Tax  Revenues  in  2007.  There  is  one  tax  policy  trigger  for  the  second 
subprogram. The Government is committed to increasing tax revenues by up to 0.5% of GDP in 

 

  

24 
 

 

2007. Over the medium term, the Government is committed to raise tax revenues from 13.0% in 
2005  to  15.5%  of  GDP  by  the  end  of  2009.  This  will  be  important  for  meeting  budget  deficit 
targets as well as for mobilizing resources for planned increases in social spending and public 
investments.  
 
65. 
Strengthening  Tax  Administration.  Improving  taxpayer  registration  will  help  to  raise 
revenues  and  reduce  the  national  government  deficit  in  2007.  Therefore,  the  trigger  for  the 
second subprogram is to clean, update and expand corporate and business registration in the 
BIR  database.  Gaining  access  to  accurate  and  complete  data  is  a  priority  for  BIR,  for  both 
collections  and  taxpayer  auditing.  Additional  milestone  actions  in  support  of  tax  administration 
include (i) completing implementation of rules and regulations under the Lateral Attrition Law; (ii) 
centralizing the database for all tax credit certificates, and (iii) implementing and strengthening 
enforcement of the risk-based audit selection developed at BOC.

Strengthening  Public  Expenditure  Management.  There  are  two  triggers  for  the

spending  allocations  and  obligations.  Over  the  medium  term,  the  Government  will  expand  the 
number of agencies with systems that disclose full budget details

Investment Climate and Infrastructure 

70. 
Reduction  in  the  Number  of  Regulations  Governing  Business  Start-ups  and 
Operations.  There is one trigger for the second subprogram.  The anti-red tape task force will 
prepare  a  medium-term  strategy  for  business  regulatory  reform  aimed  at  reducing  regulations 
affecting  business  start-ups  and  operations.  Two  supporting  milestone  actions  will  be  (i)

The  NEDA  Infrastructure  Committee  will  issue a  priority  investment  list  to  DBM  by  the  start  of

72.  More  Public–Private  Participation.  Over  the  medium  term,  further  progress  will  be 
made  to  improve  the  policy  framework  for  infrastructure  investment,  including  more  private 
sector participation. A clear framework for public–private partnerships (PPP) will be developed, 
including  procedures  and  institutional  jurisdiction  relating  to  use  of  Government  credit 
enhancements and financial participation, developing the concept, and framing the structure for 
a  dedicated  unit  to  plan  and  monitor  PPP  projects  in  compliance  with  the  PPP  framework.  In 
addition, the Government will formulate an inter-modal transport strategy.  
 
73. 
Impact and Outcomes of the DPSP Cluster. By the end of 2009, the DPSP-supported 
program is expected to have further improved the Philippine investment climate. It is anticipated 
that  the  investment  to  GDP  ratio  will  have  increased  from  15%  (2005)  to  17-19%  of  GDP  by 
2009  and  that  the  share  of  public  investment  in  GDP  will  have  increased  by  1-2  percentage 
points. This progress will be achieved by reducing the transaction costs of doing business (as 
reflected  in  the  reduction  in  the  number  of  days  to  start  up  a  business),  eliminating  all  export 
fees and charges, and increasing private participation in infrastructure.  
 

4. 

Social Inclusion 

74. 
There  are  no  social  sector  policy  triggers  for  the  second  subprogram.  However,  there 
are  three  milestone  actions  that  will  lay  the  groundwork  for  the  third  subprogram:  (i)  the 
Government will continue to advocate the adoption of the CBMS and other tools in LGUs (the 
target is for 50% of LGUs to be using the CBMS by the end of 2009); (ii) the Government will 
undertake  an  impact  assessment  of  the  Self-Employment  Assistance–Kaunlaran  program  and 
the Kapit-Bisig Laban sa Kahirapan–Comprehensive and Integrated Delivery of Social Services 
program, with a view to improving their effectiveness and targeting, and (iii) the Government will 
conduct  surveys  of  basic  education  to  facilitate  literacy  mapping  and  school  mapping,  and  to 
prioritize  school-based  management,  with  a  view  to  improving  teacher–student  ratios  and 

 

  

26 
 

 

Important Features 

classroom–student  ratios,  identifying  priority  areas  for  health  and  nutrition  programs,  and 
targeting beneficiaries through an education voucher system.  
 
75. 
Social  Welfare  Strategy.  The  Government  plans  to  develop  a  social  welfare  and 
protection  reform  strategy  during  the  period  of  the  DPSP.  A  medium-term  expenditure 
framework  is  being  developed  for  social  welfare,  protection  and  development  directed  at  the 
poverty  reduction  targets  of  the  MDGs  and  the  MTPDP,  and  improving  social  services  for 
vulnerable  sectors  of  the  population.  In  addition,  the  DPSP  will  support  the  formulation  of  the 
Government’s  strategy  to  improve  delivery  of  public  services  with  a  focus  on  continuing  to 
prioritize  implementation  of  health  sector  reforms  and  basic  education,  and  for  developing  a 
social  protection  framework  to  enhance  and  complement  the  impact  of  economic  growth  on 
poverty reduction.        
 
76. 
Impact and Outcomes of the DPSP Cluster. By the end of 2009, the DPSP-supported 
program will have improved systems for poverty monitoring and targeting. About 50% of LGUs 
will have adopted the CBMS, and Government targets for elementary and high school survival 
rates,  and  child  immunization  coverage  will  have  been  met.  In  addition,  the  implementation  of 
the  MTEF  for  education  and  health  sectors,  as  well  as  improved  procurement  procedures  will 
increase  allocations,  and  improved  budget  management  will  prepare  the  ground  for  more 
availability of resources as a result of fiscal consolidation.  
 
D. 
 
77. 
The DPSP cluster has a number of distinct and innovative features. First, the Philippines 
has demonstrated its strong ownership by coordinating all the principal development partners in 
formulating  a  consistent  and  well-sequenced  policy  framework  for  fiscal  and  cross-cutting 
structural reforms over the medium term. The program is consistent with the Paris Declaration 
on  Harmonization  and  Alignment.  The  development  partners’  strategies  and  approaches  have 
been aligned with the Government’s MTPDP for 2004–2010 and with the PDF.  
 
78. 
Second,  the fiscal and cross-cutting policy framework, including the full implementation 
of  the  MTEF,  coordinates  well  with  the  ADB’s  sector  reform  programs,  which  are  designed  to 
broaden  and  deepen  the  DPSP  (e.g.,  the  Health  Sector  Development  Program, 30 Financial 
Market  Regulation  and  Intermediation  Program, 31  and  the  Power  Sector  Development 
Program). 32 Although  these  programs  are  not  part  of  the  policy  actions  in  the  DPSP,  they 
support its scope and objectives and ensure that there is regular policy dialogue.   
 
79. 
Third, the DPSP cluster is a particularly appropriate instrument for strengthening ADB’s 
partnership  with  the  Government  and  enhancing  relations  with  other  constituencies  in  the 
Philippines. Traditional structural adjustment lending in the Philippines has had a poor record of 
success  in  recent  years  and  has  damaged  the  reputations  of  the  Government  and  its 
development partners. The DPSP provides a unique opportunity for the development partners to 
engage  with  the  Government  in  a  more  innovative  way.  By  basing  financial  assistance  on 
completed actions derived from the Government’s own reform program, the DPSP offers a new
