E. 
 
The Government has requested a loan of $250,000,000 to finance subprogram 1 of the 
81. 
DPSP, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB's  LIBOR-based  lending  facility;  a  15-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years;  and 
such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the 
draft  Program  Loan  Agreement  presented  to  the  Board.  The  Government  has  made  its  own 
independent decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, and it has given an 
undertaking that this choice was not made on the basis of any advice from ADB. 
 
The ADB funds are to support the reforms outlined in the development policy letter and 
82. 
policy  matrix  (Appendix  2,  Table  A2.1).  The  loan  size  was  determined  by  the  strength  of  the 
policy  package,  its  development  impact,  the  importance  of  the  sectors  covered,  and  the 
development financing needs of the Government, as estimated by the DOF. The political costs 
involved  in  implementing  the  reforms  are  considerable.  The  eventual  economic  benefits  will 
greatly outweigh the costs, but the costs dominate in the short term. At present, vested interests 
benefit  from  weak  governance  in  the  revenue-collecting  agencies  and  in  the  selected  line 
ministries  and  there  is  a  risk  that  their  resistance  may  delay  key  reforms.  Delays  in 
implementing  the  governance  and  fiscal  reforms  could  have  substantially  higher  costs  for  the 
economy  than  the  adjustment  costs,  as  such  delays  would  hurt  fiscal  consolidation  and  the 
economy. Direct adjustment costs include the following: (i) foregone revenues resulting from the 
elimination of fees and charges on exports, which ADB staff estimates suggest could be as high 
as  $40  million  annually;  (ii)  further  reductions    in  the  revenues  of  the  relevant  agencies  as  a 
result  of  future  reductions  in  red  tape;  and  (iii)  the  costs  of  carrying  out  improvements  to  the 
public financial management systems, including GFMIS, e-NGAS, and of establishing systems 
for disclosing budget releases and disbursements on the DBM website.  
 
83. 
The program loan reflects the development financing needs of the Government (Table 3). 
While  the  DPSP  supports  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reduce  the  Government  and  CPSD 
budget  deficits,  the  Government’s  gross  and  net  financing  needs  will  be  significant  if  it  is  to 
achieve its target of 7% economic growth by 2009, create 1 million new jobs annually, and raise 
spending  on  the  social  sectors.  The  Government  aims  to  increase  development  and  social 
spending in 2007 and as a result envisages a targeted Government deficit of no less than 1% of 
GDP. Gross and net financing needs are larger than the planned Government deficit, because 
of the amortization of external and domestic debt. According to DOF budget reports, the gross 
financing  (external  and  domestic)  requirements  for  2006  are  estimated  at  P531  billion  and  for 
2007  at  P390  billion.  Net  financing  requirements  (after  amortization  of  external  and  domestic 

 

  

28 
 

 

debt) stand at P150 billion in 2006 and are projected at P87 billion for 2007. The Government’s 
debt  management  strategy  is  to  diversify  its  liability  portfolio  by  increasing  the  weight  given  to 
domestic  debt  financing,  lengthening  the  debt  maturity  profile,  and  maximizing  overseas 
development  assistance  financing.  Based  on  the  Government’s  debt  strategy  for  2007  (the 
expected disbursement period for subprogram 1) the DOF projects gross external borrowings at 
P131  billion  ($2.59  billion).  An  ADB  staff  assessment  of  debt  sustainability  indicates  that  the 
Government’s  debt  stock  and  strategy  are  sustainable  over  the  medium  term  provided  fiscal 
consolidation  remains  on  track.  The  DPSP  proposed  loan  amount  of  $250  million  will  help  to 
close the financing gap for 2007.

3. 

Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements  

 
86. 
The program loan of $250 million will be released in a single tranche upon effectiveness 
(i.e.,  all  conditions  in  the  subprogram  1  policy  matrix  in  Appendix  2,  Table  A2.1,  must  be 
satisfactory  complied  with  prior  to  release  of  the  tranche).  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to 
finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and 
procured in ADB member countries, excluding the items specified in the negative list of ineligible 
items  (Appendix  9)  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  In 
accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and 
Related Requirements for Program Loans,33 the proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed 
to the Republic of the Philippines as the Borrower. No supporting import documentation will be 
required,  if  during  each  year  that  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  disbursed  the  value  of 
Philippines  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports  financed  under  other  official  development  assistance  is  equal  to  or  greater  than  the 
amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during such year. The Government will certify its 
compliance  with  this  formula  with  each  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation 
under  existing  procedures  will  be  required.  Disbursements  will  be  made  under  the  simplified 
procedures for program loans. In accordance with the simplified disbursement procedures and 
related requirements for program loans, all goods and services produced and originating in ADB 
member  countries  will  be  procured,  with  due  consideration  to  economy  and  efficiency,  in 
accordance  with  the  Government’s  standard  public  procedures  and  normal  private  sector 
commercial  practices  acceptable  to  ADB.  Goods  commonly  traded  on  the  international 
commodity market will be procured in accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade and 
acceptable to ADB.  
 
87. 
The  reform  needs  supported  under  the  DPSP  will  be  met  through  local  currency 
counterpart  funds  generated  from  the  proceeds  of  the  DPSP  loan.  The  DPSP  will  enable  the 
Government  to  re-orient  its  public  expenditures  toward  high-priority  poverty  reduction  needs, 
including protecting spending on social policy. 
 

4. 

Anticorruption and Fiduciary Issues 

ADB’s  policy  on  Anticorruption  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  the 
88. 
Government.  All  relevant  ADB  guidelines,  including  the  Procurement  Guidelines  (2006,  as

time  to  time),  and  the  Loan  Regulations,  were  specifically  brought  to  the  notice  of  the 
Government. 
 
89. 
A  core  component  of  the  DPSP  cluster  focuses  on  reducing  corruption  in  key  national 
government agencies vulnerable to such practices. The DPSP cluster includes reforms to public 
expenditure  management  through  the  MTEF,  and  measures  to  improve  transparency  and 
accountability  in  budget  allocations,  releases  and  disbursements  in  agencies  with  large 
procurement  budgets  (e.g.,  DPWH,  DOH,  DepED,  and  DA).  These  reforms  are  important  to 
enable  civil  society  to  monitor  budget  releases  as  they  will  increase  the  availability  of  budget 
and  disbursement  information.  The  DPSP  cluster  supports  the  work  of  the  OMB  and  DOF  in 
reducing corruption in the key revenue-collecting agencies of BIR and BOC through such anti-
corruption initiatives as RATE, RATS, and RIPS (para 56). The DPSP cluster supports OMB’s 
IDRs  of  key  national  government  agencies  as  a  way  of  identifying  weaknesses  in  national 
Government  agencies’  systems  and  procedures  that  may  increase  their  vulnerability  to

V. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

95. 
The  proposed  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  NEDA,  DOF,  and  DTI  to 
implement  and  monitor  key  policy  reforms,  and  in  particular  to  broaden  and  deepen  the 
investment policy reform agenda during the DPSP period. Under component 1, it will carry out a 
provincial  competitiveness  survey  of  businesses  and  construct  a  provincial  competitiveness 
index  to  help  the  Government  to  monitor  the  impact  of  reforms,  identify  emerging  issues 
affecting the investment climate, and track progress in economic governance in the provinces. 
Under component 2, it will strengthen analytical support for the Government’s efforts to facilitate 
private sector development in the services sector, with a focus on emerging growth sectors in 
the domestic distribution sector. Under component 3, it will support efforts by NEDA, DTI, and 
DOF to improve competitiveness through efficient trade and investment policy frameworks.  
 
96.  
The TA is estimated to cost a total of $1,150,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF).  The  Government  will  provide  the  remaining  $350,000  equivalent  by  providing 
counterpart  staff  and  other  facilities.  A  team  of  international  and  national  consultants  will 
implement  the  TA  activities.  A  consulting  firm  or  firms  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  to  implement 
Components  1  and  2,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants,  using 
simplified  technical  proposals  under  quality-  and  cost-based  selection.  A  team  of  international 
consultants will be recruited on an individual basis to implement activities under component 3, in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants,  using  the  competitive  selection 
method.  A total of 50 (19 international and 31 national) person-months will be required. The TA 
purpose,  outputs,  methodology,  implementation  arrangements,  and  budget  are  in  Appendix  7, 
and the terms of reference of consultants are in Supplementary Appendix 4.

transparency and accountability in public expenditure programs. In the infrastructure sector, the 
Government’s  policy  framework  for  public–private  participation  will  improve  private  sector 
confidence in investing in public infrastructure projects.   
 
99. 
Social.  The  DPSP’s  will  make  several  contributions  to  the  social  sector.  First,  it  will 
reduce  wasteful  spending,  and  support  Government  measures  to  align  its  resources  with  its 
medium-term  objectives  of  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  Second,  through  fiscal 
consolidation, additional resources will be made available for increased spending on productive 
social  policy.  Third,  the  DPSP  will  help  improve  the  governance  structure  in  key  social  sector 
agencies (e.g., the DepEd and the DOH) thereby preparing the ground for more availability of 
resources as a result of fiscal consolidation. Appendix 5 presents a summary poverty reduction 
and social impact mitigation strategy. 
 
100.  Economic.  The  nature  of  the  DPSP  does  not  allow  for  quantitative  financial  and 
economic  analysis  of  the  impact  of  the  policy  reforms  on  the  economy.  However,  significant 
general  economic  benefits  will  accrue  to  the  entire  population  from  the  policy  initiatives  under 
the four core areas of the DPSP. Fiscal consolidation will stabilize the economy and encourage 
new investments to occur. An improved fiscal situation will increase the resources for productive 
social  spending  and  public  infrastructure.  Improvements  in  the  investment  climate  and 
infrastructure  policy  framework  will  reduce  transaction  costs  and  uncertainty  to  the  private 
sector and encourage economic growth and improvements in productivity.  

 

  

33

101.  Resettlement,  Indigenous  People,  and  Environment. The DPSP will cause no direct 
or indirect involuntary resettlement, nor will it lead to any issues affecting indigenous peoples. 
Based  on  a  desk  review,  the  measures  supported  under  the  DPSP  are  unlikely  to  have  any 
adverse environmental impacts.

The  elections  for  Congress  in  2007  will  not  affect  policy  actions  under 
subprogram  1  as  they  had  been  accomplished  by  mid-October  2006.  However, 
the  elections  may  delay  legislative  reforms  and  slow  the  reform  momentum  in 
2007  if  there  are  personnel  changes  at  the  senior  level  in  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies. However, many of the triggers for subprogram 2 involve 
implementing legislative reforms or issuing executive orders in 2006 and thus the 
risk  to  the  overall  reform  agenda  is  relatively  low.  The  Government  remains 
committed  to  closely  monitoring  the  economic  impact  of  the  reforms  adopted 
under the DPSP, with support from ADB and the other development partners.  

The external environment may deteriorate if persistently high oil prices result in a 
slowdown  in  world  economic  growth  and  trade,  and  create  unfavorable 
conditions in  world  financial  markets.  This  would  translate  into  slower  growth  in 
the Philippines and increase fiscal stress. However, to a certain extent, this may 
be  mitigated  by  the  Government’s  policy  reform  package,  which  includes  tax 
reforms  and  reduction  of  wasteful  public  spending  through  rationalization.  The 
Philippines continues to show a high resilience to oil price shocks. 

The Government may lack commitment to implement reforms, and there may be 
weak coordination among government agencies. However, the Government has 
full  ownership  of  the  DPSP  reform  program,  which  is  embedded  in  the 
Philippines  Development  Forum.  The  Government  has  taken  a  clear  policy 
stance on the need for rapid policy adjustment on the domestic front following the 
fiscal and macroeconomic instability of 2002–2004.   

The capacity of agencies to implement reforms may be constrained by resources 
and  other  emerging  priorities  during  elections  in  2007.  However,  many  donors 
are supporting the reforms through technical assistance.  

There  will  be  resistance  to  the  reforms  from  vested  interests.  Institutionalizing 
governance reforms in the BIR, BOC, and selected line ministries is likely to be a 
long drawn-out process. There have been disappointing outcomes in recent high- 
profile corruption cases. However, several factors mitigate these risks. First, the 
DPSP  strategic  approach  is  to  focus  efforts  on  supporting  the  Government’s 
initiatives (a) to improve integrity in revenue collection in the BIR and BOC and 
(b) to strengthen public expenditure management in four national agencies with 
significant  procurement  budgets  for  infrastructure  and  the  social  sectors  (the

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

Fiscal Sustainability  

The  sector  analysis  provides  a  summary  assessment  of  the  fiscal  policy,  governance 

1. 
indicators and performance, and social inclusion.  
 
A.  
 
2. 
This section assesses fiscal policy reforms to date and summarizes the discussion of the 
key medium-term fiscal policy issues. While much has been done to put fiscal policy on a sound 
path, two critical issues face the Government over the medium term: priority spending must be 
allowed  to  grow,  and  further  reforms  must  be  built  on  these  recent  fiscal  gains  and  fiscal 
sustainability ensured in the medium term. We conclude that sustainable adjustment will require 
more  efforts  to  raise  revenues  over  the  next  few  years,  rebalance  expenditure  away  from 
statutory  outlays  to  spending  on  infrastructure  and  social  sectors,  and  strengthen  debt 
management systems. The Government has outlined a fiscal consolidation strategy supported 
by the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP).    
 

1.  

Background to the Fiscal Problem  

4

5

6

110

NFPS deficit

Figure A4.1:  NFPS Deficit and Debt as Share of GDP 

 
3. 
After  improving  in  the  first  half  of  the  1990s,  the  Philippines’  fiscal  fortunes  quickly 
reversed following the Asian crisis. In the mid-1990s, budget revenues increased markedly and 
non-financial  public  sector  (NFPS)  budget  was  almost  balanced,  and  public  debt  on  a  clearly 
declining path. Fiscal reforms in the late 1980s to the mid-1990s—including the introduction of 
value  added  tax  (VAT)  in  1988—helped  improve  fiscal  sustainability  in  the  mid-1990s.  Then 
came the Asian crisis and, exacerbated by domestic political instability, tax revenues plunged, 
the NFPS deficit increased sharply, and public debt began to climb. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
4. 
The first fiscal reform was started under the administration of President Corazon Aquino 
in  1986  and  included  the  introduction  of  the  VAT  in  1988,  which  replaced  a  multi-rate 
manufacturers’  tax,  and  changes  in  individual  and  corporate  income  tax.  The  VAT  was 
expanded in 1994 to include services that were previously subject to percentage taxes, and the 
the  comprehensive  tax  reform  package  (CTRP)  was  introduced  in  1997.  Under  the  CTRP,  ad 
valorem taxes on tobacco products and alcoholic beverages were replaced with specific excises, 
and  the  taxation  of  petroleum  products  was  revamped  by  substantially  reducing  import  tariffs 
and  introducing  excises.  Despite  trade  liberalization  and  the  resulting  reduction  in  customs 
import  duties,  the  tax  reforms  helped  increase  the  national  Government  tax  ratio  by  almost  3 
percentage points of GDP from 1990 to 1997.

However, the revenue gains from these reforms were not sustained. Figure 3 shows that 
5. 
national Government tax revenues declined by over 4 percentage points of GDP from 1997 to 
2004. About one third of the decline resulted from the continuing trade liberalization and another 
third from lower excise taxes that were not indexed to inflation. The remainder of the decline can 
be attributed to lower income tax collection (1.0% of GDP) and weaker indirect taxes, including 
VAT (0.5% of GDP).   
 
6. 
Three factors contributed to the deterioration in the fiscal balance after 1997. First, the 
financial  positions  of  the  large  government  owned  and  controlled  corporations  (GOCCs) 
deteriorated.  A  substantial  proportion  of  GOCC  losses  emanated  from  the  National  Power 
Corporation (NPC). Some of this decline came as a result of unfavorable contracts between the 
NPC  and 
the 
deterioration in NPC’s revenues was the Government’s decision to cap increases in electricity 
tariffs and a number of subsequent pro-consumer tariff decisions. Consequently, GOCCs losses 
in the NFPS budget amounted to 1.5% of GDP in 2003 and 1.8% in 2004. 
 
A second factor is that budget allocations are biased toward statutory outlays—including 
7. 
government wages, transfers to local government units and interest payments—over spending 
on  infrastructure  and  maintenance.  The  statutory  expenditure  outlays  in  total  Government 
expenditure  went  up  by  over  11  percentage  points  to  75% in  2005  over  the  1990 level  (Chart 
A4.1). This marked change in expenditure composition led to a less flexible budget, which has 
limited  discretionary  expenditure  policy  over  the  past  few  years  to  cuts  in  capital  and 
maintenance spending as well as spending in education and health sectors.

8. 
A third factor contributing to the deterioration of the fiscal balance was that the revenues 
that  boosted  tax  revenues  in  the  1990s  were  undermined  because  (i)  important  sectors, 
including  energy,  were  exempted  from  VAT;  (ii)  the  income  tax  base  was  eroded  by  a 
proliferation of tax incentives in new growth sectors of the economy; (iii) specific excises were 
not  indexed  to  inflation;  and  (iv)  tax  administration  weaknesses  persisted  and  were  not 
addressed, including updating and modernizing the taxpayer registry and addressing corruption 
in the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) and Bureau of Customs (BOC).

Appendix 4 

2.  

Fiscal Reform Program 

 
9. 
Since 2004, the Government has made important progress in solving the fiscal problem. 
It  has  launched  a  comprehensive  fiscal  reform  program.  The  program’s  cornerstone  and  the 
measure with the highest revenue impact is the VAT reform in November 2005, which extends 
the VAT base to energy products, and an increase in the VAT rate from 10% to 12% effective in 
February 2006. Other measures supporting fiscal consolidating included raising excise taxes on 
alcohol and tobacco products by 30% at the end of 2004 (although not fully indexed to inflation), 
and increasing the corporate income tax rate from 32% to 35%. The Government is also actively 
pursuing  a  rationalization  program  to  reduce  wasteful  spending  and  improve  public  service 
delivery.  Finally,  progress  has  been  made  in  reducing  the  deficits  of  large  GOCCs,  including 
increasing electricity tariffs—a measure that has reversed National Power Corporation’s deficit 
to a positive net income position of P86 billion (about $1.7 billion) in 2005.

10.  Considerable fiscal gains have been achieved following the introduction of these reforms. 
Tables A4.1 and A4.2 present key fiscal indicators to show the progress that has been made to 
improve  fiscal  consolidation  since  2004.  Revenues  have  performed  strongly  in  2006  to  date. 
Tax revenues grew by 19% through to November year on year, with VAT revenues growing by 
64%.1 Tax revenues looked set to rise by more than 1 percentage point of GDP in 2006, the first 
increase of any significance in a decade.  As a consequence of these reforms, the NFPS deficit 
was cut in half from 5.0% of GDP in 2004 to 2.1% in 2005 and is expected to fall further to 1.8% 
of  GDP,  aided  by  the  greater-than-expected  decline  in  the  Government  deficit—estimated  at 
1.8% of GDP in 2006, well below its programmed target deficit of 2.1%.

3.  

Medium-Term Fiscal Policy Issues 

 
11. 
Considerable fiscal gains have already been achieved following the introduction of these 
reforms,  but  it  will  be  important  to  lock  in  and  build  up  on  these  gains.  The  Government  has 
outlined a medium-term goal to eliminate both the national government and public sector deficits 
by 2008. The adjustment must be sustainable. This will require continuing to raise tax revenues 
and not suppressing spending on infrastructure and social sectors.  
 
Issue 1: Priority spending should be allowed to grow. Much of the brunt of the tight 
12. 
fiscal policy since 2004 has been suppressed spending on primary expenditure, particularly on 
social sectors and infrastructure (Table A4.2). For example, the 2.0 percentage point reduction 
in national Government budget deficit from 2003 to 2005 comprised 1.4 percentage points from 
expenditure  reduction  and  only  0.6  percentage  point  from  increased  tax  revenue.  In  2006, 
however, tax revenues played a bigger role in deficit reduction than in the past: the estimated 
deficit  reduction  of  1.0  percentage  point  comprises  a  0.2  percentage  point  reduction  in 
expenditures and 0.9% increase in tax revenues. Moreover, the Government of the Philippines 
spends less on the social sectors compared to many of its regional neighbors. At about 2.9% of 
GNP, the Philippines spends much less on education than in Malaysia (8.7% of GNP), Thailand 
(4.7% of GNP), and India (4.1%), but higher than in Indonesia (1.3%).2 
 
The Government intended to channel 30% of additional VAT revenues (estimated at P30 
13. 
billion) to infrastructure and social sectors (education and health) in 2006, and initially targeted a 
17%  increase  in  primary  spending  in  the  2006  budget.  The  impasse  over  the  2006  budget 
resulted 
the  2005  budget,  and  Congress  recently  approved  a 
supplementary  budget  of  P46  billion  (0.8  %  of  GDP).  The  Government  has  reported  that  it  is 
spending  less  than  programmed  in  these  areas  as  a  result  of  the  reenactment  of  the  2005 
budget.  With  the-better-than  expected  reduction  in  its  budget,  the  Government  intends  to 
accelerate  spending  on  priority  sectors  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  2006.  However,  national

Government  spending  is  expected  to  fall  short  of  program  by  about  0.5%  of  GDP  in  2006 
because  of  lags  in  disbursements  (Table  A4.2).  Part  of  the  shortfall  will  be  recovered  in  the 
2007  budget.  Congress  recently  approved  the  national  Government  budget  for  2007,  which 
targets  an  increase  in  expenditure  on  the  social  sectors  by  about  P30  billion  (or  12%)  and 
national  Government  infrastructure  by  P11  billion  (16%)  over  the  adjusted  budget  for  2006, 
meaning that the increase over actual spending in 2006 will be much larger. The Government’s 
medium-term goal is to raise public investment by as much as 1.5 percentage points of GDP by 
2009.  
 
14. 
Issue  2:  Over  the  medium-term,  sustainable  fiscal  consolidation  will  require 
further  revenue  effort.  While  the  VAT  reform  marks  an  important  advance  in  this  area, 
international  comparison  suggests  that  there  is  much  upside  potential  to  improving  revenue 
performance.  Alternative  medium-term  outlooks  for  fiscal  policy  are  in  Table  A4.4,  which 
presents two scenarios based on assumptions about further fiscal policy reforms. Scenario one 
assumes  no  additional  reforms  in  2007  over  current  measures  up  to  2006,  and  includes  the 
Government’s  medium-term  objective  of  increasing  in  capital  outlays.  The  second  assumes 
additional  reforms  (rationalization  of  investment  incentives  and  tax  administration).  The  first 
scenario shows a marked slowdown in progress toward fiscal sustainability compared with 2006, 
with a persistent NFPS deficit of 2% of GDP and a slower reduction in pubic debt. Implementing 
further reforms in 2007 would accelerate the shift toward fiscal sustainability and accomplish the 
Government’s  targets  of  a  near-balanced  public  sector  budget  by  2008/09,  with  public  debt 
falling  to  60–65%  of  GDP.  While  the  scenarios  are  indicative,  they  demonstrate  the  need  for 
continuing fiscal reforms.

Issue  4:  Debt  management  policy  needs  strengthening 

 
15. 
Issue  3:  Medium-term  fiscal  sustainability  requires  rebalancing  expenditure 
composition  away  from  statutory  outlays  to  ensure  adequate  financing  of  infrastructure  and 
social sectors. Increased public investment will improve fiscal sustainability by raising potential 
economic growth and therefore the tax take. 
 
to  ensure  debt 
16. 
sustainability  over  the  long  term,  including  addressing  contingent  liabilities.  Some 
progress  has  been  made  in  debt  management  in  recent  years,  particularly  in  lengthening  the 
average  maturity  of  Government  debt  and  in  maintaining  a  diverse  portfolio  of  obligations. 
However,  more  progress  is  needed  to  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  the  budget  and  economy  to 
macroeconomic  fluctuations.  The  growing  stock  of  debt  outside  the  Government’s  own 
borrowing program, such as GOCC and government financial institution debt, and the challenge 
of  accurately  quantifying  and  assessing  the  level  of  contingent  liabilities,  as  well  as  assets  of 
GOCCs, add to the risks.

B.  
 
18. 
In  September  2006,  the  World  Bank  released  Governance  Matters  2006:  Worldwide 
Governance Indicators, which looks at aggregate and individual country governance indicators 
for 1996–2005 in 213 countries. The indicators measure six dimensions of governance: (i) voice 
and accountability, (ii) political stability and absence of violence, (iii) government effectiveness, 
(iv) regulatory quality, (v) rule of law, and (vi) control of corruption. There is no country-specific 
governance assessment of the Philippines, but the report shows that it has been faltering in its 
drive  against  corruption  over  the  past  10  years,  on  the  basis  of  governance  indicators  that 
downgrade the country from 121 to 126 place.  

 
19. 
The  indicators,  nevertheless,  show  an  improvement  from  the  preceding  year  in  most 
categories.  For  example,  percentile  rank  in  political  stability/no  violence  was  17.5  in  2005  up 
from 12.3 in 2004, government effectiveness 55.5 up from 50.2, regulatory quality 52.0 up from 
47.3, and rule of law 38.6 up from 32.7. The country’s percentile rank means that it is better off 
than 55.5% (e.g., in case of government effectiveness) of the 213 countries. The perception of 
decreasing gains against corruption is reinforced because the country ranked 50.5% in 1998 in 
the  control  of  corruption  indicator  and  has  slid  to  37.4  percent  in  2005,  though  this  masks  a 
slight improvement over 34.8 in 2004.  

 

 62 

Appendix 4 

 
20. 
Concerns have been raised regarding the data’s objectivity. The study acknowledges the 
limitations  of  the  measures  as  the  aggregate  indicators  consist  of  276  variables  measuring 
different  dimensions  of  governance.  The  data  for  such  estimations  are  taken  from  31  sources 
produced  by  25  organizations,  compiled  through  surveys  of  firms,  individuals,  and  other 
organizations. The report did not use the country’s premier pollster, the Social Weather Station, 
as  a  survey  source,  which  portrays  a  more  positive  picture.  Any  broad  cross-country  or  over-
time  comparisons  of  governance  need  to  take  into  account  the  margins  of  error  that  are 
necessarily  associated  with  perception-based  indicators.  The  margins  of  error  also  reflect  the 
pervasive  difficulties  of  measuring  governance,  as  it  is  not  easy  to  perfectly  capture  complex 
concepts such as corruption, government effectiveness, or voice and accountability. The study 
also concludes that the aggregate indicators can “be a rather blunt tool for policy advice at the 
country  level”.  This  suggests  that  any  governance  assessment  should  also  factor  in  a 
government’s  reform  program  and  cite  efforts  or  progress  in  achieving  the  stated  good 
governance and anticorruption goals. 

 
There is also a flip side to the image presented by these indicators. The recent record 
21. 
revenue  collections,  declining  poverty  incidence,  and  the  decreasing  number  of  firms  bribing 
government officials show that government efforts to curb corruption are making some headway. 
The  Bureau  of  Customs  and  Bureau  of  Internal  Revenue,  two  of  the  more  corrupt  agencies, 
have posted record revenue collections for this year, which points to improved performance and 
reduced  corruption.  This  has  largely  been  possible  with  the  ongoing  anticorruption  measures 
and  programs  of  these  agencies,  such  as  the  revenue  integrity  protection  service  (RIPS),  run 
after  tax  evaders  (RATE),  and  run  after  smugglers  (RATS).  A  recent  survey  of  the  Social 
Weather  Station  found  that  the  number  of  companies  paying  bribes  for  public  contracts  has 
gone  down  from  57  percent  in  2003  to  46  percent  in  2006.  Though  the  figure  is  still  high,  the 
improvement cannot be overlooked. 

 
The  Government  has  an  ongoing  governance  and  anticorruption  reform  program  to 
22. 
develop  government  systems  and  processes  to  manage  public  finance,  the  civil  service,  and 
accountability. The salient features of this reform program are (i) improving public expenditure 
management  by  preparing  a  budget  strategy  paper,  projecting  forward  estimates,  rolling  out  a 
web-enabled  e-budget  system  to  increase  transparency  in  budget  releases,  rolling  out  an 
electronic accounting system to national agencies, designing and implementing the government 
integrated  financial  management  and  information  systems  (GIFMIS),  and  strengthening  audit 
execution  and  follow  up;  (ii)  strengthening  performance  management  and  improving  public 
service  delivery  by  adopting  the  organizational  performance  indicator  framework  (OPIF), 
rationalizing  the  government  compensation  system,  rationalizing  government  agencies,  and 
implementing other concomitant civil service reforms; (iii) reforming procurement through public 
disclosure  of  contract  awards  and  prices  by  agencies  with  high  procurement  volumes;  (iv) 
pursuing convictions in high-profile cases, quickly resolving corruption cases, strengthening the 
Office of the Ombudsman, and preparing agency-specific integrity development reviews.  

 
23. 
In  2006,  Sandiganbayan,  the  high  anticorruption  court,  convicted  seven  officials, 
including two mayors; 74 officials have been dismissed from service for corruption, including a 
customs deputy commissioner and Commission on Election (Comelec) bidding officials. Integrity 
development  reviews  have  been  completed  for  the  five  “high-risk”  government  agencies, 
including  BOC,  BIR,  Land  Transportation  Office,  Department  of  Public  Works  and  Highways, 
and Philippine National Police. These reviews promote and strengthen measures the agencies 
to make them more public-friendly and to enhance transparency in their operations.

The  rationale  of  the  DPSP  stems  from  a  multi-pronged  premise:  (i)  to  further  improve  overall 
governance  emerging  as  a  result  of  the  Government’s  reform  program,  (ii)  to  ensure  that 
improving  public  expenditure 
increased  government  revenues  are  spent  efficiently  by 
management  and  procurement,  and  (iii)  to  ensure  that  graft  and  corruption  cases  are 
expeditiously prosecuted.

Social Inclusion 

28.  What  conclusions  can  we  draw  from  the  above  discussion?  First,  the  data  must  be 
interpreted  carefully  to  avoid  subjective  bias.  The  data  cannot  be  divested  from  the  ongoing 
country reform programs and should be interpreted against the backdrop of any such initiatives 
to  get  a  holistic  picture.  Second,  there  can  be  no  denying  that  the  Philippines  has  significant 
governance and corruption problems, but it has also made  important progress that should not 
be overlooked. From a high peak in 1998, the six World Bank indicators deteriorated over the 
next few years but most are improving. It may well be some time before they regain their 1998 
levels, but the process can be accelerated by supporting the Government’s reform efforts. Third, 
the DPSP recognizes this reality. It not only “rewards” the Government’s fiscal performance but 
also  endeavors  to  strengthen  the  systems  that  will  help  sustain  fiscal  gains  by  strengthening 
governance  in  public  financial  management  and  procurement.  In  addition  to  areas  covered 
under  the  DPSP,  other  equally  important  reforms  are  needed  to  strengthen  the  judiciary  and 
build  capacities  in  local  governance  and  fiscal  management,  for  which  modes  of  interventions 
may be identified.  
 
C.  
 
29. 
The  poverty  incidence  in  the  Philippines  has  declined  more  rapidly  in  recent  years  but 
remains  higher  than  its  regional  neighbors’.  The  Government’s  family  income  expenditure 
survey  (FIES),  conducted  every  3  years,  estimated  that  poverty  incidence  had  declined  from 
33%  in  2000  to  30%  in  2003.5   Estimates  using  a  consumption  threshold  of  $2  per  day  show 
poverty  incidence  in  the  Philippines  to  have  declined  from  46.7%  in  2000  to  41.9%  in  2005, 
which  (comparing  2005  estimates)  is  less  than  in  Indonesia  (44.4%)  or  Viet  Nam  (49.1%)  but 
higher  than  in  Thailand  (22.8%)  or  the  PRC  (28.6%).  Its  higher  incidence  and  slower  decline 
than other East Asian countries’ reflect the modest per capita growth in the Philippines over the 
past 25 years, weakness in transforming a given rate of per capita income growth into poverty 
reduction  (i.e.,  lower  income  growth  elasticity  of  poverty  than  most  other  Asian  developing 
countries),  and  problems  in  the  effectiveness  and  targeting  of  Government  programs  for  the 
poor.  The  high  regional  income  and  asset  inequality  blunts  the  effect  of  income  growth  on 
poverty;  the  estimated  income  inequality  measured  by  the  Gini  coefficient  is  relatively  high  at 
0.468  for  2003.  Prolonged  conflict  in  parts  of  the  country  has  also  limited  economic 
opportunities and the benefits of growth to the poor. 6  However, GDP growth averaging about 
5.5% and rapid increases in remittances during 2003–2006 are expected to more quickly reduce 
poverty in the 2006 FIES.  
 
The  Philippines  has  made  better  progress  in  achieving  the  MDGs  than  other  regional 
30. 
economies,  particularly  reducing  extreme  poverty;  child  mortality;  the  incidence  of  HIV/AIDs, 
tuberculosis  and  malaria;  improving  gender  equality  in  education;  and  improving  households’ 
dietary intake as well as access to safe drinking water. Serious challenges in maternal health, 
access  to  reproductive  health  services,  nutrition,  primary  education,  and  environmental 
sustainability. Considerable disparities across regions persist, as do severe funding constraints 
(Table A4.7).

31. 
The  country  may  not  meet  the  MDG  of  universal  primary  education  by  2015.    The 
probability of achieving the MDG and Education for All targets for elementary and high school 
cohort  survival  is  low,  and  that  of  increasing  elementary  participation  is  medium.    While  high 
school  participation  rates  increased  in  2001/02  from  58%  to  60%  in  2003/04,  elementary 
participation  rates  have  fallen  from  97%  in  1999/00  to  88.4%  in  2003/04.  Elementary 
participation  rates  have  fallen  from  96.95  in  1999/00  to  88.58  in  2003/04.  Because  of  poor 
transition rates between the two levels of education, few children (38% in 2003) graduate from 
high school.  The persistent underperformance of the education system in important skill areas 
for economic development is illustrated by the comparative data on achievement: in 2003, the 
Philippines  ranked  23rd  of  25  countries  in  the  grade-4  mathematics  and  science  tests  in  the 
Trends  in  International  Mathematics  and  Science  Studies  test.    The  impact  of  compressed 
funding for education has been worsened by rapid population growth: real government spending 
per  student  fell  by  an  average  of  3  percent  per  annum  from  2000  to  2004.    Weak, 
overcentralized  governance  and  inequality  in  resource  allocation  have  contributed  to  poor 
school  performance,  especially  for  the  rural  poor,  and  are  reflected  in  marked  inequality  in 
school achievement. Functional literacy rates varied from 95% to 63% across the 17 regions in 
2003. 
 
32. 
The  Philippines  might  not  meet  the  MDG  for  reducing  child  malnutrition,  reducing 
maternal mortality, and increasing the prevalence of couples practicing responsible parenthood. 
Low health service quality and problems of financial and physical access for the poor lie behind 
this poor performance.  Catastrophic health care costs and loss of earnings because of ill health 
are a leading cause of chronic poverty.  Public spending on health ($14 per capita per year, for 
national, local government, and social health insurance spending combined) and total spending 
on health ($33 per capita per year and 3.1% of GDP) are low for a country at the Philippines’ 
level  of  economic  development,  and  have  remained  static  for  the  past  8  years.    (The 
comparable figures for lower-middle-income countries average $33.94 for public expenditure on 
health, and $81.60 or 5.6% of GDP for total expenditure).

Contribution  of  the  sector  or  subsector  to  reduce  poverty  in  Philippines:  The  Development  Program  Loan 
(DPSP) focuses on four policy areas: (i) improved fiscal sustainability, macroeconomic stability, and creditworthiness; 
(ii) improved governance in the public sector; (iii) strengthened investment climate; and (iv) protected social sectors. 
The  DPSP  policy  areas  largely  correspond  with  those  of  the  Government  as  spelled  out  in  the  Medium-Term 
Philippines  Development  Plan  (MTPDP)  2004–2010,  which  focuses  on  five  core  areas:  (i)  economic  growth  and  job 
creation;  (ii)  energy  dependency  and  power  sector  reforms;  (iii)  social  justice  and  basic  needs;  (iv)  education  and 
youth  opportunities;  and  (v)  anticorruption  measures  and  governance.  The  MTPDP  mission  is  to  “fight  poverty  by 
building  prosperity  for  the  greatest  number  of  Filipino  people.”  The  country  must  open  up  economic  opportunities, 
maintain sociopolitical stability, and promote good stewardship—all to ensure better quality of life. 
 
The Government must first solve the fiscal problem if it is to achieve a sustained and accelerated pace of growth. For 
the  second  consecutive  year,  the  Government  has  been  improving  its  tax  collection.  The  VAT  reform  is  producing 
results,  as  well  as  the  intensified  collection  performance  by  BIR  and  BOC,  through  the  new  governance  measures: 
revenue  integrity  protection  service  (RIPS),  run  after  tax  evaders  (RATE),  and  run  after  the  smugglers  (RATS), 
together with implementation of the Lateral Attrition Act, which provides incentives to BIR and BOC officials to collect 
taxes  and  duties  more  efficiently.  At  the  same  time,  the  expenditures  through  the  first  semester  were  less  than 
anticipated.  The  increased  revenue  will  be  used  to  reduce  public  debt,  and  to  finance  infrastructure  and  social 
services.  In  2007,  an  additional  P6.7  billion  will  be  released  for  social  services,  including  a  school  feeding  program 
(P1.5 billion), health insurance subsidy (P1.0 billion), hospital assistance (P0.5 billion), and textbooks (P0.5 billion). 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  
 
The poverty incidence dropped from the revised estimate1 of 27.5% in 2000 to 24.7% in 2003, as earnings rose across 
all  income  levels,  except  among  the  top  10%  of  families.  The  number  of  families  living  below  the  poverty  line  was 
reduced from 4.183 million in 2000 to 3.966 million in 2003. The country’s annual per capita poverty threshold reached 
P12,267  in  2003,  up  by  7.1%  compared  to  the  revised  2000  level  of  P11,451.  Thus,  a  family  of  5  members  should 
have an income of at least P5,111/month to be able to sustain their minimum basic needs, both food and non-food. 
The  annual  per  capita  food  threshold  increased  by  5.5%,  from  P7,707  in  2000  to  P8,134  in  2003.  Subsistence 
incidence,  or  the  proportion  of  families  with  per  capita  income  below  the  food  threshold,  stood  at  10.4%  in  2003, 
exhibiting a decrease of almost 2.0% from 12.3% in 2000. In 2003, about 1.664 million families did not earn enough 
income to provide for their basic food requirements, representing a drop from the 2000 level of 1.850 million families.2 
 
The  MTPDP  contains  ambitious  poverty  reduction  targets.  The  stated  goal  is  to  reduce  the  poverty  incidence  of 
families from 28.4% in 2000 to 17.9% in 2010. Similarly, the subsistence incidence of families is intended to drop from 
13.1% in 2000 to 8.98% in 2010. This would allow the Philippines to meet the target of halving poverty by 2015, one of 
the  commitments  to  the  UN  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  The  poverty  target  assumes  a  reduction  in 
population growth rate from 2.34% in 2000 to 2.11% in 2000-2005 and 1.93% in 2005-2010, as well as a significant 
reduction in inequality, indicated by the decline in Gini coefficient from 0.43 in 2000 to 0.35 by 2010. 
 
Progress in achieving the MDGs is mixed. While the probability is high that the Philippines will meet the poverty target, 
as  well  as  the  targets  on  gender  equality  and  child  mortality,  meeting  other  targets  by  2015  will  be  more  of  a 
challenge.  Concerted  efforts  will  be  required  to  meet  the  targets  for  universal  primary  education,  maternal  health, 
environmental sustainability, and combating diseases such as tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS.

Appendix 7         69 

 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

Issues 

Introduction 

A. 
 
To support the implementation of the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP), the 
1. 
Government  of  the  Philippines  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide 
advisory technical assistance (TA). The objectives of the TA grant are twofold, first, to support 
the  Government  (National  Economic  and  Development  Authority,  Department  of  Trade  and 
Industry,  and  Department  of  Finance  in  implementing  and  monitoring  the  impact  of  key  policy 
reforms  and,  second,  to  broaden  and  deepen  the  investment  and  trade  policy  reform  agenda 
under the DPSP. This requires analytical inputs and institutional capacity building to equip key 
agencies to continue to broaden and deepen the reform agenda. The TA concept clearance was 
approved by C. Lawrence Greenwood Jr. (vice-president operations 2) on 10 November 2006. 
The scope of the TA therefore parallels the DPSP, covering principally the investment climate 
component  and  impact  and  outcomes  listed  in  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  in 
Appendix 1.  
 
B. 
 
2.  
The challenge for the Government is to lift investment rates to create jobs for hundreds 
of thousands of the new job seekers each year and the increasing pool of unemployed. Key to 
higher  economic  growth  is  the  private  sector,  but  it  is  not  keeping  pace  with  its  neighbors 
because  the  investment  climate  is  perceived  as  not  supportive.  Recent  surveys  identify 
weaknesses  in  the  investment  climate  that  are  major  impediments  to  higher  and  more 
sustainable  economic  growth.  Several  surveys  on  business  climate  perception  suggest  that, 
among other factors, excessive red tape, remaining distortions in the trade regime, the domestic 
competitive  environment,  taxes,  contract  enforcement,  macroeconomic  instability,  corruption, 
inadequate  infrastructure  (especially  high  electricity  tariff  rates),  taxes,  economic  policy 
uncertainty,  and  customs  are  some  of  the  major  obstacles  to  private  sector  growth  and 
development. 1  These  impediments  have  combined  to  dampen  both  domestic  and  foreign 
investor confidence.  
 
At  the  same  time,  several  new  growth  sectors  are  generating  thousands  of  new  jobs. 
3. 
Many  of  the  new  sectors  are  service-based  (e.g.,  information  technology  and  back-office 
operations,  modern  retail  sector  and  domestic  distribution).  Services  have  been  the  fastest-
growing  sector,  accounting  for  about  60%  of  economic  growth  since  2000.  In  recent  months, 
several stakeholders have emphasized the importance of services in creating jobs and raising 
incomes. Many service sectors are important for their wide links with the rest of the economy. 
For example, the recent growth in supermarkets has important implications for wholesalers and 
incomes of farmers, as well as potential for exports. Private sector development and growth in 
these sectors will depend on ensuring an enabling investment climate.  
 
4.  
The TA supports a core element of the Government’s investment reform agenda. Under 
the  DPSP  cluster  the  Government  is  committed  to  lowering  transaction  costs  and  improving 
certainty  for  investors  and,  over  the  medium  term,  to  continue  with  reforms  to  improve 
competitiveness. The Government has established a task force that will prepare a medium-term 
action plan to reduce red tape and reform business regulation. The preparation of the medium-
term  action  plan  is  a  trigger  for  the  second  subprogram.  The  Government  is  preparing  a 
handbook on best practice in business registration for local governments. This TA complements 

                                                 
1 See for example, Asian Development Bank and World Bank investment climate survey in  2003–2004. 

 

 70 

Appendix 7 

another  ADB  TA  on  developing  the  Philippine  business  registry,2 as  well  as  other  activities  of 
other  development  partners,  including  the  World  Bank  and  the  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development (USAID). The World Bank is supporting public–private participation in 
transport infrastructure. USAID is providing complementary assistance for a range of investment 
issues  in  infrastructure  and  regulatory  reform  under  the  EMERGE  project.  ADB  has  worked 
closely  with  development  partners  in  preparing  the  TA,  and  will  continue  to  do  so  during 
implementation to ensure efficient use of resources.   
 
C. 

The Technical Assistance 

1. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  TA  will  support  the  DPSP  cluster  by  (i)  providing  the  Government  with  timely 
5 
economic policy analysis and advice on investment policy and competitiveness issues, and (ii) 
strengthening  institutional  capacity  in  Government  to  deepen  the  investment  climate  reform 
agenda, to implement the reforms and monitor progress and impact.  
 
6. 
Impacts  of  the  TA  are  an  improved  investment  climate  that  will  reduce  business 
transaction costs and increase competitiveness, and help increase investment, raise sustained 
economic growth, create jobs, and reduce poverty.   
 

2. 

Methodology and Key Activities 

The key TA activities are divided into three components:  

7. 
 

(i) 

Component  1:  Provincial  competitiveness  survey  and  index.  The provincial 
competitiveness  survey  of  businesses  will  help  the  Government  monitor  the 
impact  of  reforms  and  identify  emerging  issues  by  constructing  a  provincial 
competitiveness  index  (PCI).  The  PCI  will  be  a  national  investment  indicators 
survey  of  businesses  that  will  track  progress  in  the  Government’s  economic 
governance  agenda  for  improving  the  investment  climate  in  key  areas  of 
business  regulatory  reform,  tax  administration,  reforms  in  BOC,  and  investment 
policy,  among  other  policy  areas.  The  survey  will  strengthen  the  Government’s 
capacity to monitor and implement reforms and be a tool for identifying emerging 
investment  policy  issues.  It  will  cover  most  provinces,  allowing  ADB  and  the 
Government  to  benchmark  economic  governance  across  provinces,  rank 
provinces’ performance, and identify best provincial practices. The survey will be 
carried  out  in  2007.  The  output  will  be  a  report  on  the  PCI  and  economic 
governance for private sector development. 

Component 2: Strengthening private sector development and growth in the 
distribution sector. This component will provide an analytical case study on the 
development and growth of supermarkets and their supply chains and links with 
farmers, as well as impact on household spending patterns.  The focus will be on 
the  supermarket–farmer  supply  chain  nexus  and 
better  understanding 
implications  for  public  and  private  programs  in  facilitating  growth  of  the  sector. 
The supermarket sector has been selected based on recent growth performance, 
links to farmers and the rest of the economy, job creation, and poverty. The case

(ii)

study  will  (i)  improve  understanding  of  the  development  of  the  retail  sector  and 
supply  links  with  farmers,  and  therefore  impact  on  farm  household  incomes;  (ii) 
identify regulatory and structural impediments to development and growth of the 
sector; (iii) impact of supermarkets on household spending patterns and poverty, 
and  (iv)  provide  options  for  strategy  to  support  development  and  growth  of  the 
sector, and defining the roles of the public programs.    

Component  3:  Strengthen  competitiveness  through  an  efficient  trade  and 
investment  policy  framework.  This  component  will  help  the  Government 
continue reforms to improve competitiveness by (i) building on previous work by 
others,  reviewing  and  assessing  remaining  trade  policy  distortions  (mainly  in 
agriculture),  estimating  effective  rates  of  protection,  and  outlining  options  for 
reforms  to  improve  competitiveness;  (ii)  providing  input  to  the  Government  to 
develop a strategy and mechanisms to reduce red tape and implement business 
regulatory  reforms;    (iii)  building  on  previous  work  to  assess  and  recommend 
ways to reform investment incentives and other fiscal policies consistent with the 
Government’s fiscal consolidation efforts and private sector development.  

 
Cost and Financing

(TASF).  The  Government  will  provide  the  remaining  $350,000  equivalent  by  providing 
counterpart staff and other facilities (Table A7.1).

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

9. 
NEDA  will  be  the  Executing  Agency;  NEDA,  DBM,  DOF,  and  DTI  will  be  the 
implementing  agencies.  NEDA  was  selected  because  of  its  multi-functions  of  providing 
Government with analytical support, coordinating policy formulation across the key sectors, and 
overseeing tariff policy formulation through the Tariff Commission. NEDA is also a core member 
of  the  Government  DPSP  coordinating  committee  and  responsible  for  coordinating  the 
investment  climate  component  of  the  DPSP.  DBM  was  selected  as  it  is  a  member  of  the 
Government’s  competitiveness  committee.  DOF  was  selected  as  it  is  consolidating  fiscal 
investment incentives. DTI was selected as it chairs the task force on reducing red tape and the 
competitiveness  committee  overseeing  the  Government’s  competitiveness  strategy.  NEDA  will 
provide  office  space,  counterpart  staff,  and  other  services  to  the  consultants,  and  closely 
coordinate with other stakeholders involved in TA implementation. The TA will commence on or 
about 1 March 2007 and be completed on or about 30 August 2008, coinciding with the second 
and  third  subprograms.  Procurement  of  equipment  under  component  A  will  be  done  by  the 
consulting firm in accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines. Upon completion of the project 
activities the equipment will be transferred to NEDA. 
 
10. 
A team of international and national consultants will implement the TA. A consulting firm 
or firms will be engaged by ADB to implement components 1 and 2, through simplified technical 
proposals  using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection.  For  component  3,  a  team  of  international 
consultants  will  be  recruited  on  an  individual  basis  to  implement  activities.  Consultants  will  be 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  A  total  of  50  (19 
international  and  31  national)  person-months  will  be  required.  The  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consulting services and their duration are in Supplementary Appendix 4.  
 
11.  
The consultants will regularly provide written reports in English: (i) an inception report to 
include  a  comprehensive  implementation  plan  will  be  submitted  within  4  weeks  after  the  TA 
starts;  (ii)  an  interim  report;  (iii)  progress  reports;  (iv)  a  draft  final  report  and,  subsequently,  a 
final report to be submitted before the TA ends. Specific timing and content of the reports will be 
discussed with NEDA. The reports will be submitted to NEDA and ADB.  
 
The  TA  will  produce  a  series  of  demand-driven  policy  reports  to  the  Government, 
12.  
stakeholders,  and  other  donors,  which  will  include  policy  reform  recommendations  and 
implementation  strategies.  The  reports  will  be  used  as  input  into  a  comprehensive  and 
integrated  trade  and  investment  ADB  report,  Strengthening  Institutions  for  Private  Sector 
Growth. Outline of the contents will be in Supplementary Appendix 4. The expected outputs will 
be presented at a workshop launching the results of the first provincial competitiveness index in 
early 2008.
